## Add External Connection

### Create a BigQuery external connection

Navigate to the project that you recently created. Go to BigQuery Projects

1. Click Add data
2. Google Cloud Storage

roject that you recently created. Go to BigQuery Projects

1. Click Add data
2. Google Cloud Storage

THIS IS AN IMPORTANT STEP.
1. Connection type: BigLake on AWS (via BigQuery omni)
2. Connection ID: invent-cheetah-files
3. Region: you can choose the region as customer is.
4. AWS role ID: arn:aws:iam::126985841472:role/CheetahBigQueryIntegrationRole
CLICK CREATE CONNECTION

### Add the BigQuery Google Identity to CheetahBigQueryIntegrationRole’s Trust relationships on AWS

Navigate to the new external connection you recently created and copy the identity value.

Go to AWS IAM Service.
Look for CheetahBigQueryIntegrationRole
Edit Trust relationships
Add new ID.

The trust policy now is good to go!

## Grant permissions for BigQuery developers.

Select the project → Navigate to IAM & Adminservice and choose IAM

issions for BigQuery developers.

Select the project → Navigate to IAM & Adminservice and choose IAM

For developers or data scientist at Invent can have these permissions to contribute.
Write Access:
1. BigQuery Data Editor
2. BigQuery Job User
Read Access:
BigQuery Data Viewer
Viewer
BigQuery Job User

> Info: Granting permissions may vary upon the request. Permissions can be granted on a group address as well.
record link: [https://drive.google.com/file/d/1vL0vgjHjhuQHamU5JoWG7SreRvHSPzG1/view?usp=sharing](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1vL0vgjHjhuQHamU5JoWG7SreRvHSPzG1/view?usp=sharing)

Step 1:  open cmd and run mstsc/admin → login to server
Click on Start Menu and Type regedit or Press Win + R and type regeditto open Registry Editor.

Step 2: Navigate to below location:

`HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server\RCM`

Export this registry key to a file before making any changes as a backup just in something goes wrong and we need to import it back.

Step 3: Locate the GracePeriod key, If GracePeriod key exists you will either rename it or delete it.

Step 4: If deleting is not possible it may be necessary to take ownership of the key and modify its permissions first and give admin users full control to be able to delete key as below:

Step 5: Right Click on GracePeriod key and click on Permissions

Step 6: Click on Advanced, and then click on Owner tab.

Step 7: Click on Change to change the ownership and add administrator as Owner, then click Ok.

Step 8: Select Administrator and give Full Controlpermission, click Ok.

1. Primary and intermediate certificatesYou should've received a your_domain_name.pem file from GoDaddy in an email when your certificate was issued. This .pem file contains both your primary certificate and the intermediate certificate. If you have that .pem file, you can skip to step 4.If you need to concatenate your primary certificate and your intermediate certificate in to a single file, see step 2.
2. Copy the certificate files to your serverLog in to Godaddy account and download the intermediate (.crt) and your primary certificate (your_domain_name.crt) files.Copy these files, along with the .key file you generated when creating the CSR, to the directory on the server where you'll keep your certificate and key files.Note: Make them readable by root only to increase security.

metadata.title: How to Renew SSL Certificates in *.Inventanalytics.com Websites

content:
u'll keep your certificate and key files.Note: Make them readable by root only to increase security.
3. Concatenate the primary and intermediate certificatesYou need to concatenate your primary certificate file (your_domain_name.crt) and the intermediate certificate file (DigiCertCA.crt) into a single .pem file.To concatenate the files, run the following command:cat your_domain_name.crt DigiCertCA.crt >> bundle.crt

metadata.title: How to Renew SSL Certificates in *.Inventanalytics.com Websites

Edit the Nginx virtual hosts fileOpen your Nginx virtual host file for the website you're securing.Make a copy of the existing non-secure server module and paste it below the original.Note: If you need your site to be accessible through both secure (https) and non-secure (http) connections, you'll need a server module for each type of connection.Next, add the lines in bold below: server {listen   443;ssl    on;ssl_certificate    /etc/ssl/your_domain_name.pem; (or bundle.crt)ssl_certificate_key    /etc/ssl/your_domain_name.key;server_name your.domain.com;access_log /var/log/nginx/nginx.vhost.access.log;error_log /var/log/nginx/nginx.vhost.error.log;location / {root   /home/www/public_html/your.domain.com/public/;index  index.html;}}Adjust the file names to match your certificate files:ssl_certificate should be your primary certificate combined with the intermediate certificate that you made in the previous step (e.g., your_domain_name.crt).ssl_certificate_key should be the .key file g

metadata.title: How to Renew SSL Certificates in *.Inventanalytics.com Websites

content:
made in the previous step (e.g., your_domain_name.crt).ssl_certificate_key should be the .key file generated when you created the CSR.
5. Restart Nginx.Run the following command to restart Nginx:sudo /etc/init.d/nginx restart
6. Congratulations! You've successfully installed your SSL certificate.

This document explains the steps that we need take while upgrading Airflow version for our airflow-on-k8s infrastructure.

## Responsibilities of the Airflow maintainer

Airflow maintainers should be aware of two things mainly: 1) what’s in this release, 2) what’s going to be in the next release. They should:

- Follow Airflow release cycle regularly
- Read and understand release notes
- Be aware of the Airflow roadmap and follow GitHub issues to learn about the upcoming releases
- Follow patches and take action

## Upgrade Checklist

If there is a new Airflow version that we want to use,

### Learn

1. Find its release notes here
2. Read it
3. Understand it
4. Pay extra attention to the Significant Changes and Breaking changes sections
5. Pay extra attention to config and database related changes
6. Read Airflow DB upgrade document. (You will not need to follow the steps in this document because our K8s infrastructure applies these on each deployment)

### Test

In case of data loss follow the steps here.

## Recover Delta Lake

Regardless of the cloud provider or data storage technology, you can recover Delta tables using SQL on Databricks.

> Note: Not all projects have Databricks. These need to be opened by admins if your project does not have one.

For each table that needs to be recovered, run the following SQL query in a Databricks notebook:

```sql
RESTORE TABLE delta.`/data/target/` TO TIMESTAMP AS OF <timestamp>
```

For example; if the project datastore is mounted into “/mnt/datastore“ in the Databricks workspace, and you want to rollback “operation/sales” table to 2021-01-01, run this:

```
RESTORE TABLE delta.`/mnt/datastore/operation/sales` TO TIMESTAMP AS OF 2021-01-01
```

Useful documents

ORE TABLE delta.`/mnt/datastore/operation/sales` TO TIMESTAMP AS OF 2021-01-01
```

Useful documents

- Azurehttps://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/sql/language-manual/delta-restore https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/delta/history#restore
- Amazonhttps://docs.databricks.com/sql/language-manual/delta-restore.html https://docs.databricks.com/delta/history.html#restore

1. Follow the installation guide in the s3-pit-restore project
2. Run the following in a command prompt such as Terminal, Bash, or PowerShell.s3-pit-restore -b <source-bucket-name> -B <dest-bucket-name> -p "<source-folder-prefix>" -P "<dest-folder-prefix>" -t "<time>"Parameter details:-b <source-bucket-name>: Customer datastore bucket-B <dest-bucket-name>: Usually same with <source-bucket-name>-p "<source-folder-prefix>": Optional. Name of the folder that to be restored.-P "<dest-folder-prefix>": Optional. Destination folder. It is a good practice to use this. Otherwise the program will override the actual files, meaning, if anything goes wrong, you cannot rollback. So, always use this option, check the recovered files and see that everything is ok, then move the recovered files to the right place.-t "<time>": The time that you want to time-travel. For example, "11-03-2022 09:00:00 +3". IMPORTANT: Date format is “MONTH- DAY-YEAR“. It is different the one that we used to. Be careful.

". IMPORTANT: Date format is “MONTH- DAY-YEAR“. It is different the one that we used to. Be careful.

> Note: Disclaimer: We observed inconsistencies within time-series tables when we used this program. We went over each table and fixed the issue. We might need to find a better program for this purpose.

## Recover Azure Blob

### Point-in-Time Recovery

Azure Blob supports “point-in-time recovery”, meaning, in case a data loss, we can time-travel to a specific time and restore the data.

> Note: Time-travel horizon is limited, and it should be configured manually through the Azure Portal.Portal > Storage Accounts > yourstoraggeaccount > Data Protection > Enable point-in-time restore for containers

You can restore a container using Azure Portal. It is under Storage Accounts > *yourstorageaccount* > Containers.

re a container using Azure Portal. It is under Storage Accounts > *yourstorageaccount* > Containers.

1. Select the container that you want to restore.
2. Click the “Restore Containers > Restore selected” in the top menu.
3. Enter the date you want to time-travel.
4. (Optional) Enter the specific folders that you want to restore.
5. Click “Restore”

Please read the following Azure documentation for more details, and to understand the concept well.

- https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/blobs/point-in-time-restore-manage?tabs=portal
- https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/blobs/point-in-time-restore-overview

### Undelete Using Azure Storage Explorer

You can restore a data after deleting it using Azure Storage Explorer by changing the viewing of blob versioning. By default, Azure Storage Explorer shows active blobs of containers.

the viewing of blob versioning. By default, Azure Storage Explorer shows active blobs of containers.

By changing which version we would like to see in container, we can access soft deleted or previous versions any data which has been deleted.

After changing which version we would like to display, user can right-click any data that’s been deleted and restore it by selecting either simply Undelete or if the user want to go back to a certain version of that data, select Undelete by Date.

In case of restoring by Date, the user must pick the date and time period for which version of the data is wanted to be retrieved as.

user must pick the date and time period for which version of the data is wanted to be retrieved as.

Soft deleted blobs have a retention period which can change depending on lifecycle rules of containers which is managed trough [portal.azure.com](http://portal.azure.com). The retention period is important in case the user wants to recover a soft deleted blob, meaning the data should be recovered within that retention period (say it is 2 days; that means the data will retain in a soft delete version for 2 days and then be completely deleted after).

For more information about blob versions:

- Azure Storage Explorer blob versioning guide

### Undelete Using Azure Python SDK

You can use the following code to undelete deleted blobs:

[https://github.com/inventanalytics/system-network-python-scripts-helper-scripts/tree/main/asb_recovery](https://github.com/inventanalytics/system-network-python-scripts-helper-scripts/tree/main/asb_recovery)

ps://github.com/inventanalytics/system-network-python-scripts-helper-scripts/tree/main/asb_recovery)

To speed up the execution of this code, you can launch an AWS EC2 instance and run the code there.

During the customer onboarding process, we should open a ticket to Cheetah team with these 3 images.

When a Databricks notebook has thrown an error that says “Failed to Authenticate”it is because the Access keys of a storage account has been rotated, and it is needed to be renewed in Databricks notebook by unmounting and mounting the containers needed.

1. Get the rotated keys (portal.azure.com → storage accounts → {inventcustomer} → Access keys→ Show the key and copy it

### 2. Unmounting the container

```
dbutils.fs.unmount("/mnt/invent-alfuttaim-datastore")
```

### 3. Mounting the container

```
import os

storage_account = "inventalfuttaim"
fs_acc_key = "access key"

# Access keys section of given storage account in Azure Portal
extra_configs = {
    f"fs.azure.account.key.{storage_account}.blob.core.windows.net": fs_acc_key,
}

container_name = "invent-alfuttaim-datastore"
dbutils.fs.mount(
    source=f"wasbs://{container_name}@{storage_account}.blob.core.windows.net",
    mount_point=f"/mnt/{container_name}",
    extra_configs=extra_configs,
)
```

metadata.title: Solve – "Azure Storage Blob Server failed to authenticate the request. Make sure the value of Authorization header is formed correctly including the signature" Issue.

    mount_point=f"/mnt/{container_name}",
    extra_configs=extra_configs,
)
```

> Info: You have to go through those steps for each container that needs to be used in the notebook

4. Update the connection strings If a DataFactory for the Customer exists

Launch Data factory

Navigate to Linked services → Azure Blob Storage

Update the storage account connection with new rotated access keys

Data transferin gerçekleşebilmesi için SSIS paketlerinin yeni server’a kurulması gerekmektedir. Integration Services Catalog (ISC) altındaki var olan SSISDB projesi kaldırılır. ISC’ye sağ tıklanıp Create Catalog deyip, default özelliklerde SSISDB isminde bir Catalog oluşturulur. Bu işlemden sonra SSISDB isminde bir database, Databases altında gözükecektir. Daha sonra TFS’te bulunan GNC projesinin son hali local’e çekilir. Proje local’de Rebuild edilerek oluşan .ispac dosyası DB Server’a deploy edilir. (Manuel deployment) Deployment için [şu](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/DEV/pages/37126179/DT+Deployment+Ad+mlar) sayfadaki adımlar takip edilir. Deployment’dan sonra SSIS projesi üzerine sağ tıklanıp, Configure seçilir. Oradan projenin alması gereken default parametreler belirlenir. Partitioning of tables that are likely to grow in databases on SQL Server or that are already large gains both performance and space on the disk. This document contains the steps used to create a partition. Since it belongs to the Study Academy customer, this database name is included in the nomenclature.

There are basically two ways to switch to partition structure. The first one can proceed by opening a new file group per partition on the physical data file, or the second method can be progressed by opening a partition on the existing primary file group. I chose the second method. The reason why I chose this was the thought that when we want to restore the database to a different server or test database, it may lead to a longer restoration period, and administrative problems may arise due to the complexity of the setup.

longer restoration period, and administrative problems may arise due to the complexity of the setup.

The most important detail that we need to determine before proceeding to the partition structure is to decide how to divide the table into sections. Our table had reached about 3.5TB and daily recording was being dropped. Therefore, it made sense to partition on a monthly basis using the "date" field.

1- First we create partition function

```sql
USE [Academy]
GO

CREATE PARTITION FUNCTION [InventoryDatePartition](date) AS RANGE LEFT FOR VALUES ( N'2022-07-18', N'2022-08-18', N'2022-09-18', N'2022-10-18', N'2022-11-18', N'2022-12-18', N'2023-01-18', N'2023-02-18', N'2023-03-18', N'2023-04-18', N'2023-05-18', N'2023-06-18', N'2023-07-18', N'2023-08-18', N'2023-09-18', N'2023-10-18', N'2023-11-18', N'2023-12-18')
```

2- We create partition scheme as much as function values

-10-18', N'2023-11-18', N'2023-12-18')
```

2- We create partition scheme as much as function values

```sql
CREATE PARTITION SCHEME [partInventory] AS PARTITION [InventoryDatePartition] TO ([PRIMARY],[PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY], [PRIMARY])
```

	[Date] ASC
)WITH (PAD_INDEX = OFF, STATISTICS_NORECOMPUTE = OFF, SORT_IN_TEMPDB = OFF, DROP_EXISTING = OFF, ONLINE = OFF, ALLOW_ROW_LOCKS = ON, ALLOW_PAGE_LOCKS = ON)

5- We need to transfer all or the desired part to this table over the table that I want to partition. For this, you need to make sure that there is space on the disk. I used the SQL Server Integration Service feature as the method for the transfer.

6- After the data is transferred to the table, the current constraint, index, etc. After creating the objects exactly in the new table, only the process of renaming the table remains. For this, the table must not be in use and the interruption must be reported. Processing time is less than 1 minute.

SELECT
OBJECT_SCHEMA_NAME(i.object_id) AS [Schema Name],
t.name AS [Table Name],
i.name AS [Index Name],
s.name AS [Partition Scheme], *
FROM sys.indexes i
INNER JOIN sys.partition_schemes s ON i.data_space_id = s.data_space_id
INNER JOIN sys.tables t ON i.object_id = t.object_id

```sql
SELECT sizes.[schema], sizes.[tableName], sizes.[partition], sizes.[rowCount], sizes.[totalSpaceMB]
FROM (
    SELECT sch.[name] AS [schema],
        t.[NAME] AS [tableName],
        p.[rows] AS [rowCount],
        ((SUM(a.total_pages) * 8) / 1024) AS [totalSpaceMB],
        CONVERT(date, prv.[value]) AS [partition]
    FROM sys.tables t WITH(NOLOCK)
    INNER JOIN sys.indexes i WITH(NOLOCK) ON t.OBJECT_ID = i.object_id
    INNER JOIN sys.partitions p WITH(NOLOCK) ON i.object_id = p.OBJECT_ID
        AND i.index_id = p.index_id
    INNER JOIN sys.allocation_units a WITH(NOLOCK) ON p.partition_id = a.container_id
    INNER JOIN sys.schemas sch WITH(NOLOCK) ON t.schema_id = sch.schema_id
    LEFT OUTER JOIN sys.partition_schemes ps WITH(NOLOCK) ON ps.data_space_id = i.data_space_id
    LEFT OUTER JOIN sys.partition_range_values prv WITH(NOLOCK) ON ps.function_id = prv.function_id
        AND p.partition_number = prv.boundary_id

rv WITH(NOLOCK) ON ps.function_id = prv.function_id
        AND p.partition_number = prv.boundary_id
    WHERE t.is_ms_shipped = 0 AND i.OBJECT_ID > 255
    AND (ps.[name] IS NULL OR (prv.[value] IS NOT NULL AND p.[rows] > 0))
    GROUP BY t.[Name], sch.[name], p.[Rows], prv.[value]
) sizes
where tableName = 'Inventory'
ORDER BY sizes.[schema] asc, sizes.[tableName] asc, sizes.[partition] desc
```

The monthly row counts of the partitioned table are as follows. The last row gives the total row count.

If we need extra more partition range we can add these partition by below codes

```sql
ALTER PARTITION SCHEME [partInventory] NEXT USED [PRIMARY];

ALTER PARTITION FUNCTION [InventoryDatePartition]() SPLIT RANGE (N'2024-01-18');
```

## Enable two-factor authentication

Version history

You can enable 2FA using a:

- One-time password authenticator. After you enable 2FA, back up your recovery codes.
- WebAuthn device.

In GitLab 14.3 and later, your account email must be confirmed to enable 2FA.

### Enable one-time password

To enable 2FA with a one-time password:

t be confirmed to enable 2FA.

### Enable one-time password

To enable 2FA with a one-time password:

1. In GitLab:Access your User settings.Select Account.Select Enable Two-factor Authentication.
2. On your device (usually your phone):Install a compatible application. For example:Cloud-based (recommended because you can restore access if you lose the hardware device):Authy.Duo.Other:Google Authenticator.Microsoft Authenticator.In the application, add a new entry in one of two ways:Scan the code displayed by GitLab with your device’s camera to add the entry automatically.Enter the details provided to add the entry manually.
3. In GitLab:Enter the six-digit pin number from the entry on your device into Pin code.Enter your current password.Select Submit.

If you entered the correct pin, GitLab displays a list of [recovery codes](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/profile/account/two_factor_authentication.html#recovery-codes). Download them and keep them in a safe place.

1. In Storage Explorer, select  View > Account Management or select the Manage Accounts button.

2. ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT now displays all the Azure accounts you're signed in to. To connect to another account, select Add an account or Sign in with Azure

3. The Connect to Azure Storage dialog opens. In the Select Resource panel, select Subscription…

4. Select Azure

5. Select your Azure Account.

6. Choose Subscription (INVENT ANALYTICS AZURE)

7. At the Explorer blade, you will see Storage Accounts you have access to.

### Step 1: Download and install an authentication app

Before you can set up 2FA on your account, you’ll need to download and install an authentication app on your device. Slack 2FA can be used with most Time-Based, One-Time Password (TOTP) applications. Here are a few options to get you started:

- iPhone: Google Authenticator, Duo Mobile, 1Password, Authy, Microsoft Authenticator
- Android: Google Authenticator, Duo Mobile, 1Password, Authy, Microsoft Authenticator
- Windows Phone: Duo Mobile

Note:Slack doesn't support Universal 2nd Factor (U2F) yet.

### Step 2: Turn on 2FA in Slack

Mobile

Note:Slack doesn't support Universal 2nd Factor (U2F) yet.

### Step 2: Turn on 2FA in Slack

1. Sign in to the appropriate workspace, and visit your Account page at my.slack.com/account/settings.
2. Next to Two-factor Authentication, click Expand. Then, click Set Up Two-Factor Authentication.
3. Enter your password, and click Use an app to retrieve authentication codes from the authentication app on your device.
4. Add a new account. In most apps, you can do this by tapping the + icon.
5. Scan the QR code by using your device's camera. If you prefer, you can choose to enter the code by hand.
6. On Slack's 2FA configuration page, enter the 6-digit verification code that your authentication app generates.
7. To finish, press Verify Code.

When you sign in to Slack, just open your authentication app and enter a code along with your password.

When connecting to a server, you'll usually need some kind of authentication to log in, whether it be a username/password or key file. Usernames and passwords are pretty straight-forward, but things can get a bit more confusing when it comes to using private keys. Not only do you need to run SSH with extra commands, but it turns out that the key file itself needs to have certain properties.

Have you run in to the warning message below, and don't know how to fix it?

```bash
Warning: Permanently added '192.168.1.1' (RSA) to the list of known hosts.
@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@
@         WARNING: UNPROTECTED PRIVATE KEY FILE!          @
@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@
Permissions 0644 for '/path/to/my/key.pem' are too open.
It is required that your private key files are NOT accessible by others.
This private key will be ignored.
bad permissions: ignore key: /path/to/my/key.pem
Permission denied (publickey).
```

metadata.title: Solve "WARNING: UNPROTECTED PRIVATE KEY FILE!" on Mac and Linux

content:
will be ignored.
bad permissions: ignore key: /path/to/my/key.pem
Permission denied (publickey).
```

It's a common error to see when trying to log in to a server via SSH and a key file, and luckily it has a relatively easy fix. But before we get to that, let's get some background on why this error shows up.

### Why am I seeing this Error?

What happened is the key you're trying to use (key.pem in the example above) is too accessible to users on the system.

This is a bad thing because then you're not the only one able to use the key, which defeats the purpose. Private keys should only be accessible to one user.

For example, if an attacker somehow gains access to any of the accounts on your system, then they'd be able access the key, as opposed to having to get access to your account specifically. This gives them too many opportunities to get to the private key.

### How can I fix it?

Like I said earlier, this is an easy fix. Just run:

```
$ sudo chmod 600 /path/to/my/key.pem

metadata.title: Solve "WARNING: UNPROTECTED PRIVATE KEY FILE!" on Mac and Linux

content:
x it?

Like I said earlier, this is an easy fix. Just run:

```
$ sudo chmod 600 /path/to/my/key.pem

```

Keep in mind that if you keep all of your keys in the `~/.ssh` directory (or any other directory, really), you may need to adjust the permissions for that directory as well. In that case, use this:

```
$ sudo chmod 755 ~/.ssh

```

And that's all there is to it. Now you should be able to use your key with no problems.

It's important to think about how to best protect your data before an incident occurs that could compromise it.

### Recommendations for basic data protection

### Lock a storage account

- Configure a lock on the storage account to protect the account from deletion or configuration changesComes with two optionsA CannotDelete lock prevents users from deleting a storage account, but permits reading and modifying its configuration.A ReadOnly lock prevents users from deleting a storage account or modifying its configuration, but permits reading the configuration.No additional cost for lock

Good for ARM or TF

Default Manual Onboards: This feature is not activated

Default Terraform Onboards: This feature is not activated

## Enable container soft delete for the storage account to recover a deleted container and its contents.

nable container soft delete for the storage account to recover a deleted container and its contents.

When container soft delete is enabled for a storage account, a container and its contents may be recovered after it has been deleted, within a retention period that you specify. See [Container Soft Delete](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/blobs/soft-delete-container-enable?tabs=azure-portal)

## Pricing and billing

There's no additional charge to enable container soft delete. Data in soft-deleted containers is billed at the same rate as active data.

# Enable and manage blob versioning

When blob versioning is enabled, then you can restore an earlier version of a blob to recover your data if it is erroneously modified or deleted. See [Blob Versioning](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/blobs/versioning-enable?tabs=portal)

lob Versioning](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/blobs/versioning-enable?tabs=portal)

> Info: After you enable blob versioning for a storage account, every write operation to a blob in that account results in the creation of a new version. For this reason, enabling blob versioning may result in additional costs. To minimize costs, use a lifecycle management policy to automatically delete old versions

# S3 bucket versioning - deletion of delete marker

To backup of files, delete markers should be deleted as script below.

`BUCKET_NAME` = bucket name

`PREFIX` = prefix for files

`{0..131}` = partition list to iterate

`.Hif4f4CRIYBBW27oW1ghJAozuEanffo` = version id to be found on file metadata

`#!/bin/bash
BUCKET_NAME=invent-alfamarttestbulkdata-datastore

sion id to be found on file metadata

`#!/bin/bash
BUCKET_NAME=invent-alfamarttestbulkdata-datastore

for i in {0..131}; do
    PREFIX="rocket_pandas/optimization/run_id=2023-09-30-store_rpl-b3f9f834/partition_id=$i/"
    echo "$PREFIX"
    keys=$(aws s3api list-object-versions --bucket "${BUCKET_NAME}" --prefix "${PREFIX}" --query 'DeleteMarkers[?IsLatest==`true`]'.Key)
    for key in $(echo "${keys}" | jq -r '.[]'); do
        echo "Deleting file: $key"
        aws s3api delete-object --bucket "${BUCKET_NAME}" --key "${key}" --version-id '.Hif4f4CRIYBBW27oW1ghJAozuEanffo' --no-cli-pager
    done
done`

Set Data Protection settings for inventtest [Recovery models]Enable Azure Backup for blobs to back up the data stored in the inventtest storage account.Enable Point-in-time restore for containers to allow restoring containers to a specific point in time.Enable Soft delete for blobs to recover accidentally deleted blobs within the retention period.Enable Permanent delete for soft deleted items to securely remove soft deleted blobs after the retention period.Enable Versioning for blobs to maintain multiple versions of the blobs in the container.Enable Blob change feed to capture and consume the blob data changes for auditing and processing.Set recovery models as an existing customer (inventalfuttaim)Configure the recovery models (e.g., backup frequency, retention policies) based on the specific requirements of an existing customer, in this case, inventalfuttaim.Set recovery models for best practicesImplement recovery models that follow industry best practices for data protection and di

st practicesImplement recovery models that follow industry best practices for data protection and disaster recovery. This may include setting appropriate backup frequencies, retention periods, and off-site storage.
3. Add a Lifecycle ruleSet for Versioning deleteConfigure the versioning policy to handle the deletion of older versions of blobs
4. Automation of Deleted blobs/versions/snaphots
5. Monitoring Costs

Delta Lake uses versioned Parquet files to store data in our cloud storage

| Storage Account | Point in Time(max restore point) | Soft Delete for Blobs(Keep deleted blobs for) | Soft Delete for Containers | Versioning |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| inventtest | 62 complete  3 days ago | 63 complete   4 days | 64 incomplete | 65 complete |
| inventhugoboss |  |  |  |  |

### 1. Mount the Storage Account to Databricks cluster

```
import os

storage_account = "storage account name"
fs_acc_key = "access key"

# Access keys section of given storage account in Azure Portal
extra_configs = {
    f"fs.azure.account.key.{storage_account}.blob.core.windows.net": fs_acc_key,
}

container_name = "container name"
dbutils.fs.mount(
    source=f"wasbs://{container_name}@{storage_account}.blob.core.windows.net",
    mount_point=f"/mnt/{container_name}",
    extra_configs=extra_configs,
)
```

content:
1- Under JIRA DBADMIN project you need to choose “Permission Request“

2- You need to choose which customer’s database that you want to access

> Info: Only one customer should be selected in 1 task. Another task should be opened for different customers

3- Priority and due date must be selected

4- In description section the details below must be written:

- Database name: (PROD, TEST or all databases of a customer)
- Type of a permission request on a database such as (Read, Write, Alter, Exec, View any definition, SQL Agent job create, etc.)

5- All permission tasks must be approved by related manager

---

> Info: You can reach customer databases server information by Cloud Setup document.

1. Install twine cli if not present:  pip3 install twine
2. Create and adjust twine repo config at ~/.pypirc such as:[distutils]
index-servers =
    internal-repository
    external-repository
[internal-repository]
repository = https://pypi.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com
username = GET_THIS_FROM_JENKINS or GET_THIS_FROM_LastPass(check item 5)
password = GET_THIS_FROM_JENKINS or GET_THIS_FROM_LastPass(check item 5)
[external-repository]
repository = https://extpypi.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com
username = GET_THIS_FROM_JENKINS or GET_THIS_FROM_LastPass(check item 5)
password = GET_THIS_FROM_JENKINS or GET_THIS_FROM_LastPass(check item 5)

3. Upload the package:twine upload invent_module_name-V.E.R.S.I.O.N-py3-none-any.whl -r internal-repositoryfor mac: (or run python instead of python3)python3 -m twine upload invent_module_name-V.E.R.S.I.O.N-py3-none-any.whl -r internal-repositorytwine upload invent_module_name-V.E.R.S.I.O.N-py3-none-any.whl -r external-repositoryfor mac: (or run python instead of python3)python3 -m twine upload invent_module_name-V.E.R.S.I.O.N-py3-none-any.whl -r external-repositoryUploading external repo may not be necessary since internal and external are already synched.

ositoryUploading external repo may not be necessary since internal and external are already synched.

content:
1. We recommend that you create an AMI as a backup as follows, in case you need to roll back your changes.When you stop an instance, the data on any instance store volumes is erased. Before you stop an instance, verify that you've copied any data that you need from your instance store volumes to persistent storage, such as Amazon EBS or Amazon S3.In the navigation pane, choose Instances.Select the instance that requires the driver upgrade, and choose Instance state, Stop instance.After the instance is stopped, select the instance, choose Actions, then Image and templates, and then choose Create image.Choose Instance state, Start instance.
2. Connect to the instance using Remote Desktop.

metadata.title: How to manually upgrade Windows 2012 Server in AWS

content:
Create image.Choose Instance state, Start instance.
2. Connect to the instance using Remote Desktop.
3. We recommend that you take all non-system disks offline and note any drive letter mappings to the secondary disks in Disk Management before you perform this upgrade. This step is not required if you are performing an in-place update of AWS PV drivers. We also recommend setting non-essential services to Manual start-up in the Services console.
4. Download the latest driver package to the instance.Or, run the following PowerShell command:Invoke-WebRequest https://s3.amazonaws.com/ec2-windows-drivers-downloads/AWSPV/Latest/AWSPVDriver.zip -outfile $env:USERPROFILE\pv_driver.zip
Expand-Archive $env:userprofile\pv_driver.zip -DestinationPath $env:userprofile\pv_drivers
5. Extract the contents of the folder and then run AWSPVDriverSetup.msi.

metadata.title: How to manually upgrade Windows 2012 Server in AWS

content:
$env:userprofile\pv_drivers
5. Extract the contents of the folder and then run AWSPVDriverSetup.msi.

After running the MSI, the instance automatically reboots and then upgrades the driver. The instance will not be available for up to 15 minutes. After the upgrade is complete and the instance passes both health checks in the Amazon EC2 console, you can verify that the new driver was installed by connecting to the instance using Remote Desktop and then running the following PowerShell command:

```
Get-ItemProperty HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Amazon\PVDriver
```

Verify that the driver version is the same as the latest version listed in the Driver Version History table. For more information, see [AWS PV driver package history](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/xen-drivers-overview.html#pv-driver-history) Open Disk Management to review any offline secondary volumes and bring them online corresponding to the drive letters noted in Step 6.

metadata.title: How to manually upgrade Windows 2012 Server in AWS

content:
offline secondary volumes and bring them online corresponding to the drive letters noted in Step 6.

If you previously disabled [TCP offloading](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/pvdrivers-troubleshooting.html#citrix-tcp-offloading) using Netsh for Citrix PV drivers we recommend that you re-enable this feature after upgrading to AWS PV drivers. TCP Offloading issues with Citrix drivers are not present in the AWS PV drivers. As a result, TCP Offloading provides better performance with AWS PV drivers.

If you previously applied a static IP address or DNS configuration to the network interface, you might need to reapply the static IP address or DNS configuration after upgrading AWS PV drivers.

---

## To upgrade Windows Server

metadata.title: How to manually upgrade Windows 2012 Server in AWS

content:
c IP address or DNS configuration after upgrading AWS PV drivers.

---

## To upgrade Windows Server

In our [EC2 User Guide for Windows](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/os-inplaceupgrade.html), we recommend you perform an in-place upgrade by using our public installation media. Please note that if you are planning to upgrade a BYOL version of Windows Server, [you will need to create your own installation media](https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/modernizing-with-aws/how-to-create-windows-server-bring-your-own-license-amis-from-on-premises-with-vm-import-export/). This [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rImpKT7lHNI&ab_channel=AmazonWebServices) demonstrates how you can upgrade a [t2.large](https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/t2/) EC2 instance running Windows Server 2012 R2. Depending on when the instance was deployed, there are additional steps that you need to take before starting, including:

metadata.title: How to manually upgrade Windows 2012 Server in AWS

content:
1. From the AWS Management Console, collect the instance ID of the Windows Server that you are going to be upgrading. You’ll need this later.
2. Ensure that you have at least 10 GB of free disk space.
3. Make sure you have the latest paravirtual (PV) drivers on the instance, by comparing to the list in our user guide.
4. Older generation systems might have the EC2ConfigService installed. This will need to be removed and replaced with our new EC2Launch service.
5. Ensure that the Amazon Systems Manager (SSM) agent is installed on the instance as well. This will allow you to run any additional automation and manage the instance going forward.
6. Go to your Amazon EC2 console, as shown in figure 1.
7. Under the Elastic Block Store dropdown, select Snapshots.Figure 1. Amazon EC2 console displaying a list of “Snapshots”

metadata.title: How to manually upgrade Windows 2012 Server in AWS

content:
Block Store dropdown, select Snapshots.Figure 1. Amazon EC2 console displaying a list of “Snapshots”
8. In Search (as shown in Figure 2), include the following filters: Owner Alias = “amazon” and Description: “Windows 2019 English Installation Media.”Figure 2. Amazon EC2 console entering Windows 2019 English Installation Media filter
9. As shown in Figure 3, select and check the snapshot. Then click on Actions and select the Create volume from snapshot from the dropdown.Figure 3. Amazon EC2 console showing snapshot list and action “create volume from snapshot”
10. When you create the volume (as shown in Figure 4), make sure you select the correct Availability Zone that your instance is located, scroll down to the end, and then select Create volume.Figure 4. The volume settings menu, how to check instance is in correct availability zone and action “create volume”

metadata.title: How to manually upgrade Windows 2012 Server in AWS

content:
lume settings menu, how to check instance is in correct availability zone and action “create volume”
11. Once you create the volume, select it to view details and attach it to the instance (as shown in figure 5).Figure 5. A successful volume creation
12. To attach the volume, select Actions. Then select Attach volume from the dropdown (as shown in Figure 6).Figure 6. The Attach Volume Details screen
13. In the Attach volume window, select the instance that you want to upgrade from the list. Then select Attach volume (as shown in Figure 7).Figure 7. Attach Volume basic details screen
14. Use RDP or Amazon Fleet Manager to connect to the instance. Then attach the volume to the Windows 2012R2 machine using Disk Management. You can use the GUI or run diskmgmt.msc from a PowerShell console.
15. Right-click on the volume and set it to Online (as shown in Figure 8).Figure 8. Use Disk Management to set the volume to “Online”

metadata.title: How to manually upgrade Windows 2012 Server in AWS

content:
set it to Online (as shown in Figure 8).Figure 8. Use Disk Management to set the volume to “Online”
16. This will mount the drive, which is now attached to the system as the d:\ drive (as shown in Figure 9).Figure 9. Volume D: is now attached to the system

It’s time to launch the upgrade: Open a PowerShell console and change the directory to the drive that you have just mounted, and submit the following command:./setup.exe /auto upgrade.

If we’ve done everything correctly, you should see a Windows Server 2019 Setup install window. Select Windows Server 2019 Datacenter edition (as shown in Figure 10).

Figure 10. Windows Powershell image. Select Windows Server 2019 Datacenter (Desktop Experience)

Continue the upgrade by following the on-screen prompts until completion. The system will restart a couple of times during the upgrade process.

Once the OS upgrade is complete, you can validate the functionality of your applications before you put the system back in production.

metadata.title: How to manually upgrade Windows 2012 Server in AWS

content:
ou can validate the functionality of your applications before you put the system back in production.

Cleanup
This approach shows you exactly how to proceed with the upgrade. No cleanup steps required!

AWS EMP
AWS can help migrate difficult legacy Windows Server applications to the latest, supported versions of Windows Server on AWS, using the End-of-Support Migration Program (EMP) for Windows Server. EMP includes tooling to migrate your legacy applications from Windows Server 2003, 2008, and 2012 to newer, supported versions on AWS. You can use the EMP tool freely as a self-service option or with the help of AWS Partners or AWS Professional Services.

Summary
In this blog post, we discussed the challenges surrounding the Windows Server EOS from a technical perspective and why you should take action to upgrade. In addition, we walked through the manual upgrade option for Windows Server 2012 and 2012 R2.

metadata.title: How to manually upgrade Windows 2012 Server in AWS

content:
grade. In addition, we walked through the manual upgrade option for Windows Server 2012 and 2012 R2.

Please keep in mind that this four-part blog series has discussed and presented many options for dealing with EOS and how AWS can help you address these issues with the use of technology, tooling, and experts.

Requirements for recovery:

- Blob versioning is enabled.
- The blob has one or more previous versions.

## Recovery procedures via Azure Portal:

1. Go to the affected blob from the Azure portal.

1. Select the ellipses (...) for the blob you want to recover.
2. Select View versions.

1. Select the version that's required to restore from.
2. Select Make current version.

## Recovery procedures via Azure Storage Explorer:

1. Go to the affected blob from the Storage Explorer.

inventfozzy blobunda invent-fozzy-datastore/dc_rpl/run_input/store_cover_period_forecasts/

1. Filter ‘Active and soft deleted Blobs’

run_date=2023-09-03 and run_date=2023-09-04 as soft deleted

1. Choose the blobs you want to recover

Click Undelete Selected.

> Info: Usually Soft delete (Recycle bin) is 4 days as default. After that blob can’t be reached.

invent-solver application

AWS Secret manager → azure/solver/prod

Gurobi Ubuntu Instances (1 and 2) (1-10.244.1.201) → /etc/default/gurobi

Variables under /etc/default/gurobi are passed to daemons: /etc/systemd/system/gurobi*

Restart gurobi daemons/services after update.

1. Move backup file to “C:\ProgramData\Tableau\Tableau Server\data\tabsvc\files\backups”
2. Run “tsm maintenance restore -f <backupfilename>”

## Introduction

The aim from this document is to list all spark k8s cluster’s resources and apps with a brief description of every item.

## Definitions:

- Scope: the scope is determine if the app/resource will be installed on the cluster for all customers (namespaces) or per customer (namespace)

## Helm Repos

- Spark Operator: Kubernetes operator for managing the lifecycle of Apache Spark applications on Kubernetes.

link: [https://googlecloudplatform.github.io/spark-on-k8s-operator](https://googlecloudplatform.github.io/spark-on-k8s-operator)

Scope: Cluster

- Jupyterhub: Notebook server (databricks notebooks alternative)

link: [https://jupyterhub.github.io/helm-chart/](https://jupyterhub.github.io/helm-chart/)

Scope: Customer

- jetstack: Cert manager

link: [https://charts.jetstack.io](https://charts.jetstack.io)

Scope: Cluster

metadata.title: Spark on k8s Clusters Apps & Resources

content:
tstack: Cert manager

link: [https://charts.jetstack.io](https://charts.jetstack.io)

Scope: Cluster

- Jupyter enterprise gateway: Runs SparkApplication ipykernel. Backend for notebooks. We’ll use this an alternative to all purpose clusters in databricks. Jupyterhub connects to gateway and request kernels. Then the gateway creates the sparkapplication and manages its lifecycle. Has its own namespace: enterprise-gateway.

link: [https://jupyter-enterprise-gateway.readthedocs.io/en/latest/operators/deploy-kubernetes.html](https://jupyter-enterprise-gateway.readthedocs.io/en/latest/operators/deploy-kubernetes.html)

Scope: Cluster.

metadata.title: Spark on k8s Clusters Apps & Resources

content:
ingress per job for Spark UI. Runs on the driver pod of the application. Deleted after termination.

Jupyterhub has several components. Jupyter enterprise gateway also has several components. We can keep track of these through the docs. We should not mix each other. Gateway runs the kernels, creates the necessary driver and executor pods. Jupyterhub connects to the gateway and provides an interactive compute UI.

Currently we are using application gateway ingress controller + cert-manager + letsencrypt for the ingresses. We might switch to traefik. Also we should consider letsencrypt quotas and staging/production servers.

## Cloud Services

### Azure

ACR: sparkonkubernetes and inventkubernetes. We will remove sparkonkubernetes dependencies when the CI/CD is ready. We are attaching inventkubernetes manually for now.

customer-identity. Used for workload identity authentication. We add a federated credential manually, give necessary permissions (data contributor etc.).

### AWS

content:
We add a federated credential manually, give necessary permissions (data contributor etc.).

### AWS

invent-spark s3 bucket: Spark jars are deployed here. CI/CD uses jars to create base images (system-network-pipeline)

metadata.title: Migrate FortiGate Firewall 100E to FortiGate Firewall 200F

content:
1. Back up the configuration of the FortiGate 100E: Login to the FortiGate 100E and go to System > Backup & Restore. Click on 'Backup' to save the configuration file to your computer.
2. Set up the FortiGate 200F: Connect the FortiGate 200F to your network and configure its basic network settings, such as the IP address and subnet mask.
3. Copy the configuration file to the FortiGate 200F: Copy the configuration file that you saved in step 1 to the FortiGate 200F. You can do this by using a USB drive, FTP, or SCP.
4. Restore the configuration file on the FortiGate 200F: Login to the FortiGate 200F and go to System > Backup & Restore. Click on 'Restore' and select the configuration file that you copied in step 3. Follow the prompts to restore the configuration.
5. Verify the configuration: After restoring the configuration, verify that all of the settings have been migrated correctly. Check that all of your policies, routing information, and firewall settings are in place.

metadata.title: Migrate FortiGate Firewall 100E to FortiGate Firewall 200F

content:
correctly. Check that all of your policies, routing information, and firewall settings are in place.
6. Update any necessary settings: The FortiGate 200F may have different hardware and software capabilities than the FortiGate 100E, so you may need to update certain settings, such as interface configurations, to take advantage of the new features.
7. Test the new configuration: Test the new FortiGate 200F to ensure that it is working properly and all the required configurations have been migrated.
8. Decommission the FortiGate 100E: Once the FortiGate 200F is fully operational, you can decommission the FortiGate 100E

---

-Migrate Policy & Objects Addresses

-Migrate Interfaces (WAN1 & WAN2 & Internal Network)

-Configure DNS Addresses and SSL certificate for DNS

Configure LDAP Servers

Import Certificates for GoDaddy, LDAP and SSL

Create SD-WAN Zones and Configure SD-WAN Rules (Do not forget to add Performance SLAs - Pinging [Google.com](http://google.com/))

Firewall Policies

In this document we create a suggestion for invent base docker images hierarchy

## OS Base images structure

Since, Docker has limited pull requests to their repositories, we started to store base images in our AWS ECR service.

With the change to the new Kubernetes images repo, the installation steps are no longer backward compatible, and we have to be explicit about the desired version for the apt source file and GPG key.

## Fix K8S Installation

Edit .cicd/build/Dockerfile

###REMOVE THESE LINES FROM DOCKERFILE###

```
RUN curl -s https://packages.cloud.google.com/apt/doc/apt-key.gpg | apt-key add - \
  && echo "deb https://apt.kubernetes.io/ kubernetes-xenial main" | tee -a /etc/apt/sources.list.d/kubernetes.list \
  && apt-get install -y kubectl=1.23.6-00
```

###ADD THESE LINE###

```
RUN mkdir -p /etc/apt/keyrings/ \
  && chmod 755 /etc/apt/keyrings/ \
  && echo "deb [signed-by=/etc/apt/keyrings/kubernetes-apt-keyring.gpg] https://pkgs.k8s.io/core:/stable:/v1.28/deb/ /" | tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/kubernetes.list \
  && curl -fsSL https://pkgs.k8s.io/core:/stable:/v1.28/deb/Release.key | gpg --dearmor -o /etc/apt/keyrings/kubernetes-apt-keyring.gpg \
  && apt-get install -y kubectl
```

---

Issue

(ENG Version)

Admin Permission:

"Admin authorization" typically refers to the highest level of access and control authority over a system or platform. Especially in software systems, admin authorization grants users permission to make extensive changes within the system and access system resources. In data processing and workflow management tools like Airflow, users with admin authorization typically have access to the following types of functions:

1. System configuration: Operations such as modifying and configuring system settings, creating and editing connections.
2. User management: Tasks like creating new users, editing existing user accounts, managing user roles.
3. Workflow management: Operations including creating, editing, starting, and stopping workflows.
4. Monitoring and logs: Tasks such as viewing system logs, debugging, managing monitoring dashboards.

. Monitoring and logs: Tasks such as viewing system logs, debugging, managing monitoring dashboards.

This authorization is typically granted to system administrators or individuals with administrative roles and is crucial for ensuring system security, effectively utilizing resources, and optimizing system performance.

Viewer Permission:

"Viewer authorization" typically denotes a limited level of access and monitoring authority over a system or platform. In workflow management tools like Airflow, when a user is granted viewer authorization, they typically have access to the following types of functions:

1. Viewing workflows: Permission to view existing workflows. They may not have the authority to configure, modify, or initiate workflows.
2. Monitoring and reporting: Monitoring the status, history, and performance of workflows. Permission to view error conditions and use monitoring dashboards.
3. Viewing logs: Authority to examine system logs and perform debugging.

use monitoring dashboards.
3. Viewing logs: Authority to examine system logs and perform debugging.

Viewer authorization is generally granted to users who only need to monitor and report on workflows. This is an appropriate level of access for users who do not require performing more critical actions such as making changes to workflows or initiating operations.

User Permission:

"User authorization" typically refers to basic user privileges on a system or platform. In workflow management tools like Airflow, when a user is granted user authorization, they typically have access to the following types of functions:

user is granted user authorization, they typically have access to the following types of functions:

1. Viewing workflows: Permission to view existing workflows. They may not have the authority to configure, modify, or initiate workflows.
2. Queue management: Viewing workflow queues, monitoring job queues, and, if necessary, the authority to stop or start workflows.
3. Monitoring and reporting: Monitoring the status, history, and performance of workflows. Permission to view error conditions and use monitoring dashboards.

User authorization allows users to track workflows and perform basic monitoring and reporting functions on the system. However, performing more advanced actions such as making changes to workflows or initiating operations typically requires additional privileges.

Public Permission:

to workflows or initiating operations typically requires additional privileges.

Public Permission:

The "Public authorization" typically denotes that content such as a file, folder, or document is openly accessible to everyone. However, in a workflow management tool like Airflow, the term "public authorization" is not used to specify a particular level of permission. In Airflow, user access rights are usually defined with specific roles such as "Viewer," "User," and "Admin." These roles determine users' abilities to manage and monitor workflows within the system. The "Public" authorization is generally used to indicate a situation where access permissions are broad or open to everyone, but there is no such specific authorization level in Airflow.

(TR Version)

Admin Yetkisi:

veryone, but there is no such specific authorization level in Airflow.

(TR Version)

Admin Yetkisi:

"Admin yetkisi", genellikle bir sistem veya platform üzerinde en yüksek düzeyde erişim ve kontrol yetkisini ifade eder. Özellikle yazılım sistemlerinde, admin yetkisi, kullanıcılara sistemde geniş bir kapsamda değişiklik yapma ve sistem kaynaklarına erişme izni verir. Airflow gibi veri işleme ve iş akışı yönetimi araçlarında, admin yetkisine sahip olan kullanıcılar genellikle şu tür işlevlere erişebilir:

1. Sistem yapılandırması: Sistem ayarlarını değiştirme ve yapılandırma, bağlantılar oluşturma ve düzenleme gibi işlemler.
2. Kullanıcı yönetimi: Yeni kullanıcılar oluşturma, varolan kullanıcı hesaplarını düzenleme, kullanıcı rollerini yönetme gibi işlemler.
3. İş akışı yönetimi: İş akışlarını oluşturma, düzenleme, başlatma ve durdurma gibi işlemler.
4. İzleme ve günlükler: Sistem günlüklerini görüntüleme, hata ayıklama, izleme panolarını yönetme gibi işlemler.

günlükler: Sistem günlüklerini görüntüleme, hata ayıklama, izleme panolarını yönetme gibi işlemler.

Bu yetkilendirme, genellikle sistem yöneticileri veya yönetici rolüne sahip kişilere verilir ve sistem üzerindeki güvenliği sağlamak, kaynakları etkili bir şekilde kullanmak ve sistem performansını optimize etmek için önemlidir.

Viewer Yetkisi:

"Viewer yetkisi", genellikle bir sistem veya platform üzerinde sınırlı düzeyde erişim ve izleme yetkisini ifade eder. Airflow gibi iş akışı yönetimi araçlarında, bir kullanıcıya viewer yetkisi verildiğinde, genellikle şu tür işlevlere erişebilir:

mi araçlarında, bir kullanıcıya viewer yetkisi verildiğinde, genellikle şu tür işlevlere erişebilir:

1. İş akışlarını görüntüleme: Varolan iş akışlarını görebilme yetkisi. İş akışlarının yapılandırması, değiştirilmesi veya başlatılması gibi işlemleri yapma yetkisi olmayabilir.
2. İzleme ve raporlama: İş akışlarının durumunu, geçmişini ve performansını izleme. Hata durumlarını görüntüleme ve izleme panolarını kullanma yetkisi.
3. Günlükleri görüntüleme: Sistem günlüklerini inceleme ve hata ayıklama yetkisi.

Viewer yetkisi genellikle iş akışlarını sadece izlemek ve raporlamak için gereken kullanıcılara verilir. Bu, iş akışları üzerinde değişiklik yapma veya işlem başlatma gibi daha kritik eylemleri gerçekleştirmeye gerek duymayan kullanıcılar için uygun bir erişim düzeyidir.

User Yetkisi:

lemleri gerçekleştirmeye gerek duymayan kullanıcılar için uygun bir erişim düzeyidir.

User Yetkisi:

"User yetkisi", genellikle bir sistem veya platform üzerinde temel kullanıcı yetkilerini ifade eder. Airflow gibi iş akışı yönetimi araçlarında, bir kullanıcıya user yetkisi verildiğinde, genellikle şu tür işlevlere erişebilir:

1. İş akışlarını görüntüleme: Varolan iş akışlarını görebilme yetkisi. İş akışlarının yapılandırması, değiştirilmesi veya başlatılması gibi işlemleri yapma yetkisi olmayabilir.
2. Kuyrukları yönetme: İş akışlarının kuyruklarını görüntüleme, işlem sıralarını takip etme ve gerekirse iş akışlarını durdurma veya başlatma yetkisi.
3. İzleme ve raporlama: İş akışlarının durumunu, geçmişini ve performansını izleme. Hata durumlarını görüntüleme ve izleme panolarını kullanma yetkisi.

çmişini ve performansını izleme. Hata durumlarını görüntüleme ve izleme panolarını kullanma yetkisi.

User yetkisi, kullanıcıların iş akışlarını takip etmesine ve sistem üzerinde temel izleme ve raporlama işlevlerini gerçekleştirmesine olanak tanır. Ancak, iş akışları üzerinde değişiklik yapma veya işlem başlatma gibi daha ileri düzeydeki eylemleri gerçekleştirmek için genellikle daha fazla yetki gereklidir.

Public Yetkisi:

Airflow'da "public yetkisi" diye bir kavram bulunmamaktadır. "Public" terimi genellikle, belirli bir kaynağın veya içeriğin genel erişime açık olduğunu belirtmek için kullanılır. Ancak, Airflow gibi iş akışı yönetimi araçlarında, kullanıcıların erişim yetkileri genellikle belirli rollerle tanımlanır. Bu roller genellikle "Viewer", "User" ve "Admin" gibi isimlendirilir ve kullanıcıların sistemdeki iş akışlarını yönetme ve izleme yeteneklerini belirler.

isimlendirilir ve kullanıcıların sistemdeki iş akışlarını yönetme ve izleme yeteneklerini belirler.

Airflow'da genellikle her kullanıcıya belirli bir rol atanır ve bu rol, kullanıcının yapabileceği işlemleri belirler. Örneğin, bir "Viewer" rolüne sahip bir kullanıcı yalnızca iş akışlarını görüntüleyebilirken, bir "User" rolüne sahip kullanıcı iş akışlarını yönetebilir ve çalıştırabilir. "Admin" rolüne sahip kullanıcılar ise genellikle sistem yapılandırması, kullanıcı yönetimi ve iş akışlarını geniş bir şekilde yönetme yetkisine sahiptir.

Bu nedenle, Airflow'da "public yetkisi" gibi bir kavram bulunmaz çünkü her kullanıcı belirli bir rolle atanır ve bu rol, kullanıcının erişim yetkilerini belirler.

Which address can I log in from?

[https://inventanalytics.okta.com](https://inventanalytics.okta.com)

What information should I use to log in?

Username: Vpn username, your computer username, or your email address. (for example: [okta.user@invent.ai](mailto:okta.user@invent.ai), okta.user)
Pass: You need to use your VPN password at this step.

I want to access an application but I can't see it on my user dashboard, what should I do?

You can create a request from the "Request an app" section located at the bottom left of your user dashboard screen.

What should I do if I forgot my username and/or password?

Since your Okta username and password are the same as your VPN username, you cannot directly reset them. You can email [alpha-team@invent.ai](mailto:alpha-team@invent.ai), ask-alpha slack channel contact the alpha team for assistance. If you are working in US you can contact with [SupportTX@velonexit.com](mailto:SupportTX@velonexit.com) for faster help.

n US you can contact with [SupportTX@velonexit.com](mailto:SupportTX@velonexit.com) for faster help.

What is the Okta Browser Extension used for?

The Okta Browser Extension serves several purposes:

Single Sign-On (SSO): Provides access to multiple applications with one login.

Auto-Fill: Automatically fills in saved credential information.

Security: Provides secure identity authentication and password management.

Why should users install it?

Installing the Okta Browser Extension allows you to:

Convenience: Enables easy and frequent access to various applications.

Security: Ensures passwords are managed securely.

Time-saving: Speeds up the login process.

You can install the Okta extension from Chrome extensions or directly from the Okta interface.

Which browsers can I use Okta on?

Supported web browsers for Okta include Microsoft Edge, Firefox, Safari, and Chrome.

How do I set up Multifactor Authentication?

ta include Microsoft Edge, Firefox, Safari, and Chrome.

How do I set up Multifactor Authentication?

If you're logging in for the first time, after entering your username and password, you'll be prompted to set up an authenticator app. Follow the instructions to set it up and use your MFA code to log in.

Note:
For detailed instructions on setting up MFA, please refer to the "First Login Action on OKTA" document.

What should I do if I don't have access to Multifactor Authentication or if I'm experiencing issues?

Multifactor authentication user operations are managed by the Alpha team. You can reach us by emailing [alpha-team@invent.ai](mailto:alpha-team@invent.ai), through the ask-alpha Slack channel, or via other communication channels such as Slack or Teams.

If you have any issues, questions, or suggestions, you can reach us at [alpha-team@invent.ai](mailto:alpha-team@invent.ai) via email, or through the ask-alpha Slack and Teams channels.

What is Okta and How Does it Work?

Okta is a platform designed for enterprise-level identity management and single sign-on solutions. It helps employees, customers, and partners securely and easily access various applications within our company.

Benefits of Okta:

Simplified Login Processes:
With Okta, accessing our work applications such as Office365 (Azure, Teams, etc.), Google Workspace, and LastPass becomes much simpler. You no longer need to remember multiple usernames and passwords. A single sign-on allows seamless access to all applications, saving time and eliminating password-related issues.

Enhanced Security:
Okta provides robust security advantages by centrally managing access controls for all applications. This minimizes the risk of unauthorized access. Additional security measures like multi-factor authentication (MFA) further safeguard our company's digital assets.

content:
rity measures like multi-factor authentication (MFA) further safeguard our company's digital assets.

Efficient User Management:
From an administrative standpoint, Okta streamlines user management processes. New employees quickly receive necessary access permissions, and access for departing employees is promptly revoked. This ensures a secure work environment.

Access Policies:
Okta allows us to set specific access rules for applications. For example, access to sensitive data may be restricted to certain locations or times, enhancing overall data security.

Features:Single Sign-On (SSO):
Sign in once to access all applications, reducing the need to manage multiple credentials.

Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):
Provides an additional layer of security beyond passwords, such as a code sent to your phone or authentication via a mobile app.

Easy and Secure User Management:
Simplifies account creation and deactivation processes, ensuring only authorized individuals have access.

metadata.title: Okta: Beginner's Guide and Usage Tips

Access Policies:
Enables granular control over application access based on predefined rules, enhancing security and compliance.

If you have any issues, questions, or suggestions, you can reach us at [alpha-team@invent.ai](mailto:alpha-team@invent.ai) via email, or through the ask-alpha Slack and Teams channels.

dbfs:/mnt/invent-alfamart/flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T031034.276Z/

Code

```
#!/bin/bash

/
dbfs:/mnt/invent-alfamart/flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T031034.276Z/

Code

```
#!/bin/bash

bucket="invent-alfamart"
folders=("flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T030534.276Z/"
         "flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T030634.276Z/"
         "flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T030734.276Z/"
         "flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T030834.276Z/"
         "flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T030934.276Z/"
         "flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T031034.276Z/")

for folder in "${folders[@]}"; do
  versions=$(aws s3api list-object-versions --bucket $bucket --prefix $folder)

  echo "$versions" | grep '"IsLatest": false' -B 2 | grep '"Key":' | awk -F'"' '{print $4}' > keys.txt
  echo "$versions" | grep '"IsLatest": false' -B 2 | grep '"VersionId":' | awk -F'"' '{print $4}' > versionIds.txt

ons" | grep '"IsLatest": false' -B 2 | grep '"VersionId":' | awk -F'"' '{print $4}' > versionIds.txt

  paste keys.txt versionIds.txt | while IFS="$(printf '\t')" read -r key version_id; do
    echo "Restoring $key (version: $version_id)"
    aws s3api copy-object --bucket $bucket --copy-source "$bucket/$key?versionId=$version_id" --key $key
  done

  rm keys.txt versionIds.txt
done

```

### Explanation:

1. List Object Versions: List all versions of the objects within the specified folders.
2. Identify Deleted Versions: The script identifies the versions that are not the latest by searching for "IsLatest": false.
3. Extract Keys and Version IDs: It extracts the keys and version IDs of the non-latest versions using grep and awk.
4. Restore Deleted Versions: For each identified version, the script uses the copy-object operation to restore it by copying it back to the same key.

### Running the Script

the copy-object operation to restore it by copying it back to the same key.

### Running the Script

1. Save the script to a file, for example, restore_deleted_folders.sh.
2. Make the script executable:

```
chmod +x restore_deleted_folders.sh
```

1. Run the script:

```
./restore_deleted_folders.sh
```

This will restore the deleted folders and their subfolders to their previous states.

Main goal of this document that explains daily cloud cost e-mail definition.

## Total Cost by Month

This table summarizes the total costs over the past three months, broken down by each cloud provider.

Columns:

Month-Year: The specific month and year for the cost data.

Total Cost: The aggregate cost incurred across all cloud providers for the specified month.

Cloud Columns: Also there exist separate columns for each provider to indicate the total costs in that provider in the indicated month.

## MTD and Monthly Costs by Source

This table provides both Month-To-Date (MTD) costs and costs for the last 31 days, compared to the corresponding previous periods, categorized by each cloud provider.

Columns:

Source: The cloud provider or source of the cost, such as AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud.

Current MTD Cost: The total cost so far in the current month.

Previous MTD Cost: The total cost during the same period in the previous month.

metadata.title: General Daily Cost Review e-Mail Definition

content:
the current month.

Previous MTD Cost: The total cost during the same period in the previous month.

Delta MTD (%): The percentage change in MTD costs compared to the previous month.

Current 31 Days Cost: The total cost over the past 31 days.

Previous 31 Days Cost: The total cost during the previous 31 days.

Delta 31 Days (%): The percentage change in 31-day costs compared to the previous 31 days.

## Daily Costs by Source

This table shows the daily costs incurred from each cloud provider for the last five days. Note that the cost for the most recent day may be incomplete due to reporting delays.

Columns:

Source: The cloud provider or source of the cost, such as AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud.

1 Day Ago Cost: The cost incurred one day ago.

2 Days Ago Cost: The cost of two days ago.

3 Days Ago Cost: The cost of three days ago.

4 Days Ago Cost: The cost of four days ago.

5 Days Ago Cost: The cost of five days ago.

metadata.title: General Daily Cost Review e-Mail Definition

content:
days ago.

4 Days Ago Cost: The cost of four days ago.

5 Days Ago Cost: The cost of five days ago.

The cost for the most recent day may not be fully reported and might be updated after a few days due to reporting delays from the providers.

> Info: Current day costs could be impartial due to cost reporting delays from the providers, for aws_databricks the reporting delay is 2 days.

## Customer Costs

This table details the costs for individual customers, comparing Month-To-Date (MTD) and 31-day costs against previous periods.

Month-To-Date (MTD): The period begins on the first day of the month and the current day. When comparing current and previous MTD it reports costs in the days of the current day of the month. If today is 13 March, it will report costs on 1-12 February for previous MTD costs and 1-12 March for current costs.

Columns:

Customer: The name of the customer.

Current MTD Cost: The total cost incurred by the customer so far in the current month.

metadata.title: General Daily Cost Review e-Mail Definition

content:
he customer.

Current MTD Cost: The total cost incurred by the customer so far in the current month.

Previous MTD Cost: The total cost incurred by the customer during the same period in the previous month.

Delta MTD (%): The percentage change in MTD costs compared to the previous month.

Current 31 Days Cost: The total cost incurred by the customer over the past 31 days.

Previous 31 Days Cost: The total cost incurred by the customer during the previous 31 days.

Delta 31 Days (%): The percentage change in 31-day costs compared to the previous 31 days.

## Virtual Machine Reservation Monthly Fixed Costs

This table provides a summary of the fixed monthly costs associated with reserved virtual machines for different customers.

Columns:

Customer: The name of the customer.

Machine Type: The type of reserved virtual machine.

Monthly Cost: The fixed monthly cost which is paid once in a month for the reserved virtual machine.

content:
# WindowsStep 1: Change EBS Volume Size in the AWS Console

1. Navigate to AWS Management Console:

Log in to your AWS account and navigate to the AWS Management Console.

1. Access EC2 Dashboard:

From the AWS Management Console, click on “Services” and select “EC2” under the Compute section.

1. Locate the EBS Volume:

In the EC2 dashboard, select the EBS volume, you wish to resize.

1. Modify Volume Size:

Click “Actions” and then select “Modify Volume.” Enter the new volume size and click “Modify.”

Click “Actions” and then select “Modify Volume.”

Increase EBS Volume Size

Alter the size of the volume as per your requirement for my case, I’m increasing is up to 40GB.

# Step 2: Extend the Partition

Log into your Windows instance, and open Disk Management. You can do this by typing in:

```
diskmgmt
```

When Disk Management opens, you will notice the volume is sized at 30GB, as it was originally.

metadata.title: How to Increase Volume Size in AWS EC2 Instances for Windows and Linux(ubuntu)

content:
```

When Disk Management opens, you will notice the volume is sized at 30GB, as it was originally.

If you open “Action,” and then “Rescan Disks,” you will see an additional 10GB of unallocated space which was just added by expanding the EBS Volume.

To use the newly added space, right click on the existing volume and choose the “Extend Volume” option.

This will bring up the Wizard which will help you make changes quickly.

Select the desired amount of space to be added (you most likely want to add all of it, as was done here), and finish the process. When you look at the usable size now, you will see that you have successfully expanded it to 40GB.

# Linux

## Ubuntu:Step 1: Change EBS Volume Size in the AWS Console

1. Navigate to AWS Management Console:

Log in to your AWS account and navigate to the AWS Management Console.

1. Access EC2 Dashboard:

From the AWS Management Console, click on “Services” and select “EC2” under the Compute section.

1. Locate the EBS Volume:

metadata.title: How to Increase Volume Size in AWS EC2 Instances for Windows and Linux(ubuntu)

content:
Console, click on “Services” and select “EC2” under the Compute section.

1. Locate the EBS Volume:

In the EC2 dashboard, select the EBS volume, you wish to resize.

1. Modify Volume Size:

Click “Actions” and then select “Modify Volume.” Enter the new volume size and click “Modify.”

Click “Actions” and then select “Modify Volume.”

Increase EBS Volume Size

Alter the size of the volume as per your requirement for my case, I’m increasing is up to 30GB.

# Step 2: Extend the Partition

1. Check Existing Partitions and File System Type:Before making any changes, it’s important to know the existing partitions and their file system types. Use the following command to display this information:

```
df -hT
```

This command provides a clear view of your file system types.

> “df -hT” is a command that tells you how much space is being used on your computer, “-h” shown in a human-readable format (like GB), and “-T” tells you what kind of storage system is being used (like NTFS or ext4).

metadata.title: How to Increase Volume Size in AWS EC2 Instances for Windows and Linux(ubuntu)

content:
format (like GB), and “-T” tells you what kind of storage system is being used (like NTFS or ext4).

df -Th command output

From the above image, you can find the “Type” section, there my file system type is “ext4”

To check the partition, use the following command:

```
lsblk
```

This command provides a clear view of your partitions

lsblk command execution

here you can find the partition mentioned as xvda1,xvda14,xvda14 as a child of xvda.

Now I need to increase the xvda1 to 30Gb, for that I need to increase partition.

1. Extend the Partition:

To adjust the partition size to utilize the available space, run the following command:

```
sudo growpart /dev/xvda 1
```

This command ensures the partition utilizes the entire available space.

Adjust the partition to use entire space

Here you can see that xvda1 is extended to my desired size.

# Step 3: Extend the File System

Next, let’s extend the file system to reflect the changes:

metadata.title: How to Increase Volume Size in AWS EC2 Instances for Windows and Linux(ubuntu)

content:
size.

# Step 3: Extend the File System

Next, let’s extend the file system to reflect the changes:

1. Check File System:Determine your file system type to choose the appropriate command for extension. For this, use:

```
lsblk
```

This will show the file system information.

1. Extend File System (Ext4):

If your file system is Ext4 (as in this case), use the following command to extend it:

```
sudo resize2fs /dev/xvda1
```

If you have an XFS file system, the command to extend is:

```
sudo xfs_growfs -d /
```

1. Verify the Extension:

To confirm the successful extension of the partition and file system, run:

```
df -Th
```

With these steps, you’ve successfully increased the EBS volume on your AWS Ubuntu instance.

metadata.title: How to Increase Volume Size in AWS EC2 Instances for Windows and Linux(ubuntu)

content:
Issue:

`ERROR: (BadRequest) Too many Federated Identity Credentials have been assigned to the Managed Identity. Code: BadRequest`

Reason:

This issue occurs when workload identity can’t add a new federated identity credential for the branch. (It has 20 federated identtiy credential limit)

Solution:

1. Go to portal.azure.com
2. Navigate to {customer}-identity → Managed Identity
3. Click “Federated Credentials”
4. Delete “unused branch federated identity credential”

Optional

1. Remove Application Gateway Listeners & Listener TLS Certificatesapplication gateway → {aks-cluster}-gateway → Listeners → Delete unused branch listeners for port 80 and 443.
2. Remove Application Gateway Listener TLS Certificate

metadata.title: Solve “Too many Federated Identity Credentials have been assigned to the Managed Identity. “ Issue

The customers that use this Airflow include:

- Apparel
- Boyner
- Flo

- Mavi

Here is the translated text:Now we will briefly explain how to perform user operations.1 - First, when a user request is received, we find the customer's create_cluster config in the customer-airflow-invent repository.You can access this list from the link below.https://github.com/inventanalytics/customer-airflow-invent/tree/master/dags/invent/config/create_cluster

2-
a) We open the YAML file.
b) In the YAML file, under the jupyter_users: section, we add the user in the same format and merge it into the master branch.

the jupyter_users: section, we add the user in the same format and merge it into the master branch.

 3 -
