### Overview

This guide covers the steps for deploying and configuring a `k8s-smtp` server in a Kubernetes cluster. The `k8s-smtp` server is responsible for handling SMTP requests within the cluster and can be configured to allow relaying for specific domains.

### Issue

Airflow deployment can’t send failed notifications

```yaml
[2024-08-01, 13:24:49 UTC] {base.py:71} INFO - Using connection ID 'smtp_default' for task execution.
[2024-08-01, 13:24:49 UTC] {configuration.py:569} WARNING - section/key [smtp/smtp_user] not found in config
[2024-08-01, 13:24:49 UTC] {email.py:229} INFO - Email alerting: attempt 1
[2024-08-01, 13:24:49 UTC] {taskinstance.py:1914} ERROR - Failed to send email to: ['alfamart-alerts-email.uh5o8nbr@invent-analytics.pagerduty.com', 'alfamart-data@inventanalytics.com']
```

### Inspect

Left: nslookup in the new cluster that does not have k8s-smtp server configured
Right: Existing cluster that has SMTP server configured

metadata.title: Installation of k8s-smtp to Kubernetes Cluster

content:
hat does not have k8s-smtp server configured
Right: Existing cluster that has SMTP server configured

Existing cluster with k8s-smtp service.

New cluster that has no k8s-smtp service.

### Deployment Files

- Deployment YAML: smtp.yaml
- Service YAML: k8s-smtp-service.yaml

### Deployment Steps

#### 1. Deploy the SMTP Server

To deploy the `k8s-smtp` server, apply the `smtp.yaml` file using the following command:

```bash
kubectl apply -f smtp.yaml
```

This command deploys the SMTP server in the Kubernetes cluster according to the specifications defined in the `smtp.yaml` file.

#### 2. Expose the SMTP Service

To expose the `k8s-smtp` service, apply the `k8s-smtp-service.yaml` file using the following command:

```bash
kubectl apply -f k8s-smtp-service.yaml
```

This command creates a service that exposes the SMTP server, making it accessible to other pods within the cluster.

### Post-Deployment Configuration

metadata.title: Installation of k8s-smtp to Kubernetes Cluster

content:
TP server, making it accessible to other pods within the cluster.

### Post-Deployment Configuration

After deploying the `k8s-smtp` server, some configurations must be made in the `main.cf` file located at `/etc/postfix/main.cf` within the pod. These configurations include setting up domain relaying and ensuring secure transmission.

#### Configuration Steps

1. Access the k8s-smtp Pod:To edit the main.cf file, first, access the running k8s-smtp pod.kubectl exec -it <pod-name> -- /bin/bashReplace <pod-name> with the name of the running pod.

1. Edit main.cf:Use a text editor to modify the main.cf file.bashCopy codenano /etc/postfix/main.cfAdd the following lines:relay_domains = invent-analytics.pagerduty.com, inventanalytics.com smtp_tls_security_level = encryptrelay_domains: Specifies the domains that are allowed to relay through the SMTP server.smtp_tls_security_level = encrypt: Ensures that TLS is used for securing SMTP communication.

metadata.title: Installation of k8s-smtp to Kubernetes Cluster

content:
server.smtp_tls_security_level = encrypt: Ensures that TLS is used for securing SMTP communication.

1. Verify the Changes:After saving the changes, verify the new configuration using:postconf -nThis command displays the active Postfix configuration parameters, allowing you to confirm that your changes have been applied.

### Final Steps

1. Reload Postfix:To apply the new configuration, reload the Postfix service within the pod.postfix reload
2. Testing:Send a test email to verify that the SMTP server is correctly handling requests and relaying messages for the specified domains.

### Conclusion

By following these steps, you will have successfully deployed and configured the `k8s-smtp` server in your Kubernetes cluster. This setup ensures secure SMTP communication and appropriate relaying for specified domains.

Files: all files under price folder.

```bash
#!/bin/bash

# Variables
STORAGE_ACCOUNT="inventboots"
CONTAINER_NAME="invent-boots-wba-datastore"
BLOB_FOLDER="operation/price"
AZURE_ACCOUNT_KEY="<your_account_key>"

# Optional: Set environment variable for storage account key
# (uncomment this line if using access key authentication)
# export AZURE_STORAGE_KEY=$AZURE_ACCOUNT_KEY

ncomment this line if using access key authentication)
# export AZURE_STORAGE_KEY=$AZURE_ACCOUNT_KEY

# List all blobs in the price folder, including versions
echo "Listing all blobs in the price folder..."
blob_list=$(az storage blob list \
    --account-name $STORAGE_ACCOUNT \
    --container-name $CONTAINER_NAME \
    --prefix "$BLOB_FOLDER" \
    --include v \
    --query "[?properties.blobType=='BlockBlob'].{name: name, versionId: versionId, lastModified: properties.lastModified}" \
    --output tsv)

# Check if any blobs are found
if [ -z "$blob_list" ]; then
    echo "No blobs found in the specified folder."
    exit 1
fi

# Process each blob and restore the latest version
echo "Restoring the latest version of each blob..."
echo "$blob_list" | while read -r line; do
    blob_name=$(echo $line | awk '{print $1}')
    version_id=$(echo $line | awk '{print $2}')

e; do
    blob_name=$(echo $line | awk '{print $1}')
    version_id=$(echo $line | awk '{print $2}')

    # Construct source URI with version ID
    source_uri="https://$STORAGE_ACCOUNT.blob.core.windows.net/$CONTAINER_NAME/$blob_name?versionid=$version_id"

    # Copy the latest version of the blob to itself, making it the current version
    echo "Restoring $blob_name to its latest version (version id: $version_id)..."
    az storage blob copy start \
        --account-name $STORAGE_ACCOUNT \
        --destination-blob "$blob_name" \
        --destination-container "$CONTAINER_NAME" \
        --source-uri "$source_uri" \
        --output none

    echo "$blob_name has been restored to its latest version."
done

echo "All blobs in the $BLOB_FOLDER folder have been restored to their latest versions."

```

### Steps to Use:

1. Replace <your_account_key> with your actual Azure Storage account key if you're using access key authentication.
2. Make the script executable:chmod +x restore_blob_versions.sh
3. Run the script:./restore_blob_versions.sh

This script should now correctly restore the latest version of each blob to be the current version without running into any errors.

1. Replace STORAGE_ACCOUNT with your actual Azure Storage Account (Example: “inventboots”, “inventfivebelow”)
2. Replace CONTAINER_NAME with your actual Azure Storage Blob (Example: “invent-boots-input”, “invent-fivebelow-output”)
3. Replace BLOB_FOLDER with your actual Azure Storage Blob Folder (Example: “operation/price”, “analysis/seasonality_sales_filter”

4. Run the script: ./update_storage_class.sh

### Summary:

–5 hours for Standard Glacier retrieval).
4. Run the script: ./update_storage_class.sh

### Summary:

- Script 1 initiates the restore requests for all objects from Glacier.
- Script 2 checks the restore status and changes the storage class to Standard for all restored objects.

The LaTeX Math for Confluence - Math Formula & Equations plugin allows you to create mathematical formulas and equations using the LaTeX language within the Atlassian Confluence platform. LaTeX is a widely used markup language for creating mathematical expressions and scientific documents. This plugin enables the easy inclusion of complex mathematical notations, scientific formulas, and equations in documents.

Key features include:

metadata.title: What is LaTeX Math for Confluence - Math Formula & Equations?

content:
plex mathematical notations, scientific formulas, and equations in documents.

Key features include:

1. Inserting Mathematical Expressions: Users can directly add various mathematical expressions (integrals, derivatives, matrices, etc.) to Confluence pages using LaTeX syntax.
2. Easy Editing: As LaTeX codes are written, the formulas are dynamically generated, making it easy to edit and preview the equations.
3. Equation Editor Support: You can manually write expressions using LaTeX commands or create equations more intuitively with a visual editor.
4. Improved Visual Representation in Documents: The visual presentation of expressions helps clarify complex mathematical concepts, making documents easier to understand.

This plugin is particularly beneficial for professionals in engineering, science, and mathematics, and is ideal for academic writing, technical documentation, or any project involving mathematical analysis.

Please visit the link below for more information:

, or any project involving mathematical analysis.

Our Dev, Test, and UAT Kubernetes clusters automatically start at 08:00 AM and shut down at 10:00 PM each day. If you need to work outside of these hours, you won’t be able to access these environments.

To work during off-hours, the cluster for the environment you’re working in needs to be running. You can do this by following the steps below:

1. First, navigate to the pipeline for the environment where you will be working.

a) [dev-aks](https://jenkins.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/job/pipelines/job/Alpha-AKS-Cluster-Starter/)

b) [eks-flux-test](https://jenkins.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/job/pipelines/job/Alpha-EKS-DEV-Cluster-Starter/)

c) [eks-staging](https://jenkins.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/job/pipelines/job/Alpha-EKS-STAGING-Cluster-Starter/)

2. Run the pipeline with the "start" parameter selected. The environment will be ready in a few minutes.

1. Once the work is complete, don’t forget to run the same pipeline with the "stop" parameter!

If you're creating a new feature branch, no changes are required(from main). However, if you need to migrate an existing branch, follow these steps:

1. Update the Jenkinsfile: First, update your Jenkinsfile. You can use the existing Jenkinsfile from the main branch for this.
2. New Build and Deploy Process: After the build and deploy process, a new namespace will be created in the customertest-eu-aks cluster, and your resources will be migrated to this namespace.
3. Airflow URL Change: After the build is complete, your Airflow URL will change to:customername-your-branch-name.customertest.airflow.inventanalytics.com(It may take 3-5 minutes for the pods to become ready after the build process.)

In this document, you will learn how to send emails using the @invent.ai domain.

Note: All users have been configured to receive emails with the @invent.ai alias.
Your default email prefix has been extended with @invent.ai, and any messages sent to this address will reach your mailbox. For example, emails sent to [test.user@inventanalytics.com](mailto:test.user@inventanalytics.com) or [test.user@invent.ai](mailto:test.user@invent.ai) will both be delivered to your inbox.”

Step-by-Step Instructions:

1. Log in to your email account.

Click on the settings icon (⚙️) and navigate to ‘See all settings’.

1. Go to the ‘Accounts’ tab:

Under the ‘Send mail as:’ section, click on ‘Add another email address’.

1. Add your new alias:

In the ‘Add another email address’ window:

- Fill in the ‘Name’ and ‘Email’ fields as shown in the example picture.

- Ensure the ‘Treat as an alias’ checkbox is selected.

- You do not need to specify a different ‘reply-to’ address.

metadata.title: How to Send Emails Using @invent.ai Alias

content:
eat as an alias’ checkbox is selected.

- You do not need to specify a different ‘reply-to’ address.

- Click ‘Next Step’ to complete the process.

1. Verify the setup:

Once you have completed the addition process, you should see a screen similar to the one shown in the picture below.

Note:You should click the ‘Make default’button to set your default sender email to the ……..@invent.ai format.

Outlook:

If you are using the Outlook application for sending and tracking emails, after completing the steps above, you can follow the steps below to send emails using an alias through Outlook as well.

metadata.title: How to Send Emails Using @invent.ai Alias

content:
1. Read (r)

- Purpose: Allows reading the content and metadata of a blob or its snapshots.
- Use Cases:
- Downloading the content of a blob.
- Accessing blob metadata and properties.
- Example: Use this permission to allow a user or application to view or download a file.

1. Add (a)

- Purpose: Grants permission to add data to an existing Append Blob or create a new blob.
- Use Cases:
- Appending data to an Append Blob without overwriting existing content.
- Example: Logging systems that continuously add entries to an Append Blob.

1. Create (c)

- Purpose: Allows the creation of new blobs or blob snapshots.
- Use Cases:
- Creating an empty blob.
- Generating snapshots for backup purposes.
- Note: This permission doesn’t allow modifying existing blobs. Use Write (w) for that.
- Example: Creating a new file or backup snapshot in Blob Storage.

1. Write (w)

metadata.title: Azure Blob Storage SAS Permissions Guide

content:
Write (w) for that.
- Example: Creating a new file or backup snapshot in Blob Storage.

1. Write (w)

- Purpose: Enables writing or overwriting blob content, metadata, and properties.
- Use Cases:
- Updating existing blob content.
- Writing metadata or properties to a blob.
- Note: For Append Blob-specific operations, use Add (a).
- Example: Overwriting a file with a new version.

1. Delete (d)

- Purpose: Grants the ability to delete blobs or blob snapshots.
- Use Cases:
- Removing unnecessary files or snapshots from Blob Storage.
- Example: Cleaning up outdated backups or files.

1. List (l)

- Purpose: Allows listing all blobs within a container.

- Use Cases:

- Retrieving a directory of available files.

- Note: Listing blobs doesn’t grant access to their content. For that, the Read (r) permission is required.

- Example: Displaying a list of files to users in an application.

metadata.title: Azure Blob Storage SAS Permissions Guide

### 1) First, migrate the customer’s TFS repository to GitHub.

- Pull the TFS repository.
- Create a repository in GitHub named customer-(customer-name)-tfs and push the code there (e.g., customer-flo-tfs).

### 2) After creating the repository, prepare the self-hosted runner.

- You can use default-runner tag. (e.g., runs-on: [self-hosted, windows, default-runner]) or create a new runner.
- Go to Settings > Actions > Runners in the repository settings and click the New self-hosted runner button.
- In the window that opens, select the operating system for the runner. Since our runner is on a Windows Server, choose Windows.

- Açılan pencereden runnerımızın işletim sistemi seçilir. Bizim runner'ımız windows server olduğu için windows’u seçiyoruz.

### 3) Set up the runner

seçilir. Bizim runner'ımız windows server olduğu için windows’u seçiyoruz.

### 3) Set up the runner

- Connect to the runner via RDP (10.244.30.69).
- Under the C:\ directory, create a folder named actions-runner-(customer-name) and run the commands necessary to install the runner in this directory.
- During the installation process, add a tag to the runner in the format runner-(customer-name).

### 4) Create the .github/workflows directory in the repository and add a ci-cd.yaml file

Below is a sample `yaml` file:

Replace the placeholders `$(customer-name)` with the actual customer name.

```
name: customer-name CI/CD Pipeline

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - test
  workflow_dispatch:

env:
  CUSTOMER_NAME: "customer-name"
  IIS_USER: ".\\github.sp"
  IIS_PASS: ${{ secrets.PASS_GITHUB_SP }}

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: [self-hosted, windows, runner-customer-name] #default-runner or runner-customer-name

d:
    runs-on: [self-hosted, windows, runner-customer-name] #default-runner or runner-customer-name

    steps:
      - name: Checkout Code
        uses: actions/checkout@v3
        with:
          fetch-depth: 1
          persist-credentials: false

      - name: Download NuGet.exe
        run: |
          Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/latest/nuget.exe" -OutFile "nuget.exe"
        shell: powershell

      - name: Restore NuGet Packages
        run: |
          .\nuget.exe restore Maps.UI/Maps.UI.csproj -SolutionDirectory .
          .\nuget.exe restore customer-name.sln -SolutionDirectory .
        shell: powershell

ory .
          .\nuget.exe restore customer-name.sln -SolutionDirectory .
        shell: powershell

      - name: Build Project
        run: |
          $vswherePath = "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\Installer\vswhere.exe"
          $msbuildPath = & $vswherePath -version '[15.0,16.0)' -products * -requires Microsoft.Component.MSBuild -find MSBuild\\Bin\MSBuild.exe
          $outputDir = "C:\actions-runner-customer-name\_work\${{ env.CUSTOMER_NAME }}-tfs\${{ env.CUSTOMER_NAME }}-tfs\publish"
          & $msbuildPath Maps.UI\Maps.UI.csproj `
            /p:Configuration=Release `
            /p:Platform=x64 `
            /p:OutDir="$outputDir" `
            /p:DeployOnBuild=true `
            /p:PublishProfile="C:\PublishProfiles\RelativeFile.pubxml"
        shell: powershell

Write-Output "Build output path exists: $buildOutputPath"
          }
        shell: powershell

      - name: Prepare Artifact
        run: |
          $artifactPath = "\\EC2AMAZ-UCJ0ADI\artifact"
          $buildOutputPath = "C:\actions-runner-customer-name\_work\${{ env.CUSTOMER_NAME }}-tfs\${{ env.CUSTOMER_NAME }}-tfs\publish\_PublishedWebsites\Maps.UI"
          if (!(Test-Path $artifactPath)) {
              New-Item -ItemType Directory -Force -Path $artifactPath
          }
          Copy-Item -Path "$buildOutputPath\*" -Destination $artifactPath -Recurse -Force
        shell: powershell

  deploy:
    runs-on: [self-hosted, windows, runner-customer-name]
    needs: build

    env:
      SERVER_IPS: ${{ github.ref == 'refs/heads/main' && '10.244.20.233 10.244.21.20' || '10.244.20.94' }}

SERVER_IPS: ${{ github.ref == 'refs/heads/main' && '10.244.20.233 10.244.21.20' || '10.244.20.94' }}

    steps:
      - name: Deploy to All Servers
        run: |
          $artifactPath = "\\EC2AMAZ-UCJ0ADI\artifact\*"
          $targetPath = if ($env:GITHUB_REF -eq 'refs/heads/main') { "C:\Deployments\Customer-name" } else { "C:\Deployments\Customer-nameTest" }
          $user = "${{ env.IIS_USER }}"
          $password = "${{ env.IIS_PASS }}"
          $serverIPs = "${{ env.SERVER_IPS }}"
          $serverList = $serverIPs -split " "

          foreach ($server in $serverList) {
              $securePassword = ConvertTo-SecureString $password -AsPlainText -Force
              $credential = New-Object System.Management.Automation.PSCredential($user, $securePassword)
              $session = New-PSSession -ComputerName $server -Credential $credential

              Invoke-Command -Session $session -ScriptBlock {
                  param ($targetPath)

$targetPath

              Remove-PSSession -Session $session
          }
        shell: powershell

      - name: Clean up Artifact Files on Runner Machine
        run: |
          Remove-Item -Path "\\EC2AMAZ-UCJ0ADI\artifact\*" -Recurse -Force
        shell: powershell
```

### Important Notes

- This pipeline is designed to deploy to production if the branch name is main, and to the test environment otherwise. Be cautious when working on the main branch!
- Test your changes on a separate branch before merging.
- Custom adjustments may be required for each customer. Check the build steps in TeamCity as needed.
- For assistance, contact the Alpha team

he Set Up button under the Security Question section to proceed.

- On the screen that follows, either select a predefined question from the dropdown menu or create your own custom question if available. Enter your answer to the chosen or custom question, and then click Verify to complete the process.

That’s it! You have successfully set up a security question for your OKTA user account.

> Info: If you have any issues, questions, or suggestions, you can reach us at alpha-team@invent.ai via email, or through the ask-alpha Slack and Teams channels.

metadata.title: How to Add a Security Question to Your OKTA User Account

content:
1. Access the Okta Website:

Go to [https://inventanalytics.okta.com](https://inventanalytics.okta.com) in your browser.

1. Log In with Your Credentials:Enter your  Username and Password on the login screen and proceed.

> Info: Information regarding the Username and Password will be provided during the System Orientation.You can log in using the username format shown in the image below, such as test.user or test.user@invent.ai.

1. Begin the Google Authenticator Setup:

Once logged in, you’ll see the Google Authenticator App screen. Click the Set up button to proceed.

> Info: Note: You’ll need to scan the QR code shown here in the next step.

1. Set Up the Google Authenticator App on Your Phone:

scan the QR code shown here in the next step.

1. Set Up the Google Authenticator App on Your Phone:

- If you don’t already have the app installed:
- iPhone users can download it from the App Store, and Android users can get it from the Google Play Store.
- To connect the app to Okta:
- Open the Google Authenticator app on your phone.
- Use the app to scan the QR code displayed on the Okta setup screen.
- The app will generate a 6-digit code that refreshes periodically.

1. Enter the Code in Okta:

On the Okta setup screen, input the 6-digit code generated by the Google Authenticator app.

1. Google Authenticator is Mandatory:

Google Authenticator is a mandatory authentication method. However, the applications shown in the image below are optional.

That said, since password changes and unlocking accounts require two-factor authentication (in addition to your password), you must set up an additional authentication method besides Google Authenticator.

to your password), you must set up an additional authentication method besides Google Authenticator.

If you have any issues, questions, or suggestions, you can reach us at [alpha-team@invent.ai](mailto:alpha-team@invent.ai) via email, or through the ask-alpha Slack and Teams channels.

> Info: Note:If you forget to set up another authentication method besides Google Authenticator, you can refer to the OKTA documentation for guidance on how to enable it later. The relevant documents are provided below.

[How to Add a Security Question to Your OKTA User Account]

[How to Set Up Passkeys with OKTA Verify on macOS Using Touch ID]

[How to Set Up Passkeys with OKTA Verify on Windows Using a Fingerprint Reader]

[How to Set Up OKTA Verify for Your Account (Mobile App)]

[How to Add a Phone Number to an OKTA User Account]

[https://inventanalytics.okta.com](https://inventanalytics.okta.com)

1. Log in to Your OKTA Account

- Start by logging in to your OKTA account.

1. Authenticate

- Proceed with your login using Google Authenticator or the authentication method you have set up.

1. Access Settings

- Once logged in, click your name in the upper-right corner. From the dropdown menu, select Settings.

1. Navigate to Security Methods

- On the Settings page, scroll down to the Security Methods tab. Locate the Phone option and click Set Up to proceed.

1. Authenticate Again

- Enter your account password and the authenticator code to continue.

1. Set Up Phone Security Method

- Under the Set Up Security Methods section, find Phone and click Set Up to proceed.

1. Enter Phone Details

- On this step, enter your country code and phone number. Then, click Receive a code via SMS to continue.

1. Verify the Code

metadata.title: How to Add a Phone Number to an OKTA User Account

content:
r country code and phone number. Then, click Receive a code via SMS to continue.

1. Verify the Code

- You will receive a verification code via SMS (e.g., “Your Okta verification code is: XXXXX”). Enter the code into the field on your screen and click Verify.

That’s it! Your phone number has been successfully added to your OKTA account.

Note: If you are unable to receive SMS due to restrictions from your mobile carrier or specific issues with your line, we recommend contacting your carrier or choosing an alternative authentication method.

> Info: If you have any issues, questions, or suggestions, you can reach us at alpha-team@invent.ai via email, or through the ask-alpha Slack and Teams channels.

Note: To change your password, you must set up an additional authenticator (Phone, Okta Verify, Security Question) other than Google Authenticator.

If you have not set this up yet, you can refer to the [How-To Articles](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ADMIN/folder/4836425758)section for guidance on how to configure it.

If you already have an additional authenticator set up, you can proceed directly with the steps below:

> Info: Note: Since your Okta password will be the same as your VPN password, after completing these steps, your computer will adapt to your new password once you connect to the VPN. Otherwise, you may encounter issues when starting your computer.

1. Go to https://inventanalytics.okta.com and log in to the Okta screen.

1. Proceed by selecting Forgot Password.

1. You can use the format test.user or test.user@invent.ai as your username.

1. For password changes, two authenticator verifications will be required.

metadata.title: How to Reset a User’s Password in OKTA

content:
ent.ai as your username.

1. For password changes, two authenticator verifications will be required.

Enter your Google Authenticator code and click the Verify button to proceed.

1. If you have an additional method set up as the second verification, you can use it on this screen.

In this example, we are proceeding using an SMS sent to the phone number linked to the account.

1. Enter the SMS code you received on your phone and click the Verify button.

1. You will now access the password reset screen.On this screen, create your new password and proceed.

> Info: Note: Password requirements are shown in the image. However, all details regarding password requirements are shared at the bottom of the page. Make sure to follow these rules when creating your new password.

Password Requirements:

- Require 3 of the following 4 criteria: lowercase letter, uppercase letter, number, symbol.

- Cannot contain part of the username.

- Cannot contain the first name.

metadata.title: How to Reset a User’s Password in OKTA

content:
se letter, number, symbol.

- Cannot contain part of the username.

- Cannot contain the first name.

- Cannot contain the last name.

- Don’t use common passwords.

- Don’t use your last 3 passwords.

- Minimum password age is 2 hours. (This means you can only change your password once every 2 hours. Therefore, please be careful when creating your password.)

> Info: Warning: If you make too many failed login or password change attempts, you may be locked out of the system for up to 10 minutes.

> Info: If you have any issues, questions, or suggestions, you can reach us at alpha-team@invent.ai via email, or through the ask-alpha Slack and Teams channels.

fy.

by entering your password and performing the authenticator verification again.

# Introduction

This document explains how to use the Kubernetes dashboard at [https://grafana.infra.prod.inventanalytics.com](https://grafana.infra.prod.inventanalytics.com) Includes only production Kubernetes clusters.

> Info: Note: All OKTA users have permission to access the Grafana page.

# Dashboards

We have 7 dashboards under the Dashboards page. You will find the details about Dashboards in the following steps.

> Info: Note for all panels: If you want to focus on a specific metric, You can enlarge it by pressing the button “v” on the keyboard, you can also reset it by pressing “esc”.

# Airflow Dashboard Testing

This Dashboard is used for the Airflow metric test so it's not in use. You can connect with Taha Çelik for more details.

# Kubernetes Clusters Global Metric Dashboard

This Dashboard shows us the Kubernetes clusters' general metrics like “cluster CPU usage“, “clusters memory usage“, “how many pods running on the cluster“ etc.

## Datasource

metadata.title: How to Use Kubernetes Monitoring Dashboards

content:
ster CPU usage“, “clusters memory usage“, “how many pods running on the cluster“ etc.

## Datasource

You can choose a Kubernetes cluster in the drop-down menu, which one you want to monitor.

## Time Range

You can choose a time range up to right. You can use  5 - 15 - 30 minutes  or hourly patterns or you can choose a specific time range

# Kubernetes Log Dashboard

This dashboard shows us Kubernetes pod logs. If you need pod logs (for example Airflow Scheduler) you need to use this dashboard.

## Datasource

You can choose a Kubernetes cluster in the drop-down menu, which one you want to monitor.

## Namespace

You must choose a specific namespace for getting logs.

## POD

You must choose a specific pod for getting logs

## Stream

The stream must choose “all“

## Search

You can search words or sentences in logs.

> Info: Note: When you change the “datasource”, namespace and pod will change automatically.

# Kubernetes Node Metrics Detailed Dashboard

metadata.title: How to Use Kubernetes Monitoring Dashboards

content:
asource”, namespace and pod will change automatically.

# Kubernetes Node Metrics Detailed Dashboard

This dashboard shows us Kubernetes nodes details like “node CPU usage“, “node memory usage“, “node uptime“, “node network usage“ etc.

## Datasource

You can choose a Kubernetes cluster in the drop-down menu, which one you want to monitor.

## Host

You can choose a specific node for the monitor in the drop-down menu

> Note: Important Note: If you have doubts that the kubernetes cluster is not scaled, you can use this dashboard.

# Kubernetes Pods Metrics Detailed Dashboard

This dashboard shows us Kubernetes pod details like “pod CPU usage“, “pod memory usage“, “pod resource request and limits“ etc.

## Datasource

You can choose a Kubernetes cluster in the drop-down menu, which one you want to monitor.

## Namespace

You must choose a specific namespace.

## POD

You must choose a specific pod

# Kubernetes Resource Request & Usage

metadata.title: How to Use Kubernetes Monitoring Dashboards

content:
a specific namespace.

## POD

You must choose a specific pod

# Kubernetes Resource Request & Usage

This dashboard was just created temporarily for Alfamart to debug an issue.

# Profiling for Python Code

This dashboard shows us Python profiling logs

## Pod Name

You must to choose pod in the drop-down menu or you can paste the pod name directly.
If you didn’t see any log please change time range

# Explore

If you need more specific metrics or logs, you can use Explore. Please follow, following steps for how to use Explore page.

### For Metrics

1. Click the hamburger menu top left and click Explore
2. Choose the Kubernetes cluster in the drop-down menu for metrics use the ending with “-metrics“, for logs use the ending with“-logs“.

1. Click “Select metric“ → “Metrics explorer“ and write in search what you want to view (for example; memory_request) and click “Select“

1. You can choose a specific namespace and pod under “label filters“

metadata.title: How to Use Kubernetes Monitoring Dashboards

content:
ry_request) and click “Select“

1. You can choose a specific namespace and pod under “label filters“

> Info: Note: You can add more filters by clicking the “+“ button

1. Click “Run query“ top right

1. If you want you can choose the time range right top

### For logs

1. Click the hamburger menu top left and click Explore
2. Choose the Kubernetes cluster in the drop-down menu for metrics use the ending with “-metrics“, for logs use the ending with“-logs“.

1. Choose “builder” to the top right  and choose the label under “Label filters“

> Info: Note: You can add more filters by clicking the “+“ button

1. Click “Run query“ top right

> Note: Note: You need administrator access to use Explore. If you need to use Explore please contact Alpha Team

`nicolaka/netshoot` image is a great choice for network troubleshooting in Kubernetes because it comes pre-installed with a variety of networking tools like `ping`, `traceroute`, `netcat`, `curl`, `tcpdump`, `dig`, and more

---

### Create a Pod with nicolaka/netshoot

You can use the following `kubectl` command to quickly create and run a pod interactively:

```
kubectl run netshoot --rm -it --image=nicolaka/netshoot -- /bin/bash
```

- kubectl run netshoot → Creates a pod named netshoot
- --rm → Deletes the pod when you exit
- -it → Runs in interactive mode
- --image=nicolaka/netshoot → Uses the nicolaka/netshoot image
- -- /bin/bash → Opens a bash shell inside the pod

Once inside, you can use various network troubleshooting tools:

→ Opens a bash shell inside the pod

Once inside, you can use various network troubleshooting tools:

- ifconfig or ip a → Show network interfaces
- ping google.com → Test connectivity
- traceroute google.com → Trace route to a host
- dig google.com → Perform a DNS lookup
- curl http://example.com → Test HTTP requests
- tcpdump -i eth0 → Capture network packets

### Alternative: Deploy as a Pod using YAML

If you want to deploy it as a standard pod:

```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  name: netshoot
  labels:
    app: netshoot
spec:
  containers:
  - name: netshoot
    image: nicolaka/netshoot
    command: ["/bin/bash", "-c", "sleep 3600"]
    tty: true
    stdin: true
```

Apply with:

```
kubectl apply -f netshoot.yaml
```

Then exec into it:

```
kubectl exec -it netshoot -- /bin/bash
```

## 💡 Step-by-Step Guide to Implement & Test Stored Access Policies for SAS Tokens

### 1️⃣ Create a Stored Access Policy on the Container

We will create a policy that defines permissions, start time, and expiration.

#### 📌 Using Azure Portal (GUI)

1. Go to Azure Portal → Storage Accounts.
2. Select your Storage Account.
3. Navigate to Containers (under Data Storage).
4. Click on the container where you want to apply the policy.
5. In the left menu, go to Access Policy.
6. Click + Add Policy and configure:Name: BootsPolicyPermissions: Select Read, Write, List (as needed).Start Time: Set to current time.Expiry Time: Set as required (e.g., 7 days from now).
7. Click Save.

---

### 2️⃣ Generate a SAS Token Using the Stored Access Policy

Now, we create a SAS token linked to the stored access policy.

#### 📌 Using Azure Portal (GUI)

metadata.title: Stored Access Policies for SAS Tokens

content:
icy

Now, we create a SAS token linked to the stored access policy.

#### 📌 Using Azure Portal (GUI)

1. Go to the container where the policy was created.
2. Click on Shared Access Signature.
3. Select the Stored Access Policy (BootsInputPolicy).
4. Click Generate SAS and connection string.
5. Copy the SAS Token URL and share it for testing.

---

### 3️⃣ Test the Generated SAS Token

- The customer should test the SAS Token to ensure they can access the container.
- This can be done via:Azure Storage ExplorerPostman / CURL requestsSDK or CLI

---

### 4️⃣ Simulating a Compromise (Revoking the SAS Token)

If the SAS token is compromised, we will remove the Stored Access Policy, which will immediately invalidate the token.

#### 📌 Using Azure Portal

1. Go to the container → Access Policy.
2. Find the policy BootsInputPolicy.
3. Click Delete and Save changes.

💡 Expected Behavior:
✅ The old SAS token should now be invalid.
❌ Any access attempt using that token should fail.

---

metadata.title: Stored Access Policies for SAS Tokens

content:
:
✅ The old SAS token should now be invalid.
❌ Any access attempt using that token should fail.

---

### 5️⃣ Generate a New SAS Token (After Revocation)

Once the policy is deleted, issue a new SAS token with a fresh Stored Access Policy.

GitHub Actions – Contributor Usage Guide

This guide is for customer pipeline projects which use *GitHub Actions* to automatically run tests, builds, and other checks when code is pushed or a pull request is opened.

As a contributor, you don’t need to modify the workflows. This guide explains how to work effectively with the existing setup.

---

🔄 What Happens Automatically

GitHub Actions runs automated workflows that used be managed by Jenkins:

- Code linting (e.g., pylint, flake8)
- Tests (rocks unit tests, dag unit tests)
- Docker image builds (build image, airflow scheduler image)
- Script Deployment (e.g., rocks_extension, scripts)(for main, dev and feature branches)
- Airflow deployments (for main, dev and feature branches)

---

✅ Your Responsibilities

1. Push Code or Open a PR

- Just push your branch to GitHub or open a pull request.
- The appropriate GitHub Actions workflow(s) will run automatically.

1. Monitor the Workflow Status

- The appropriate GitHub Actions workflow(s) will run automatically.

1. Monitor the Workflow Status

- Go to the "Checks" tab on your pull request to see the status.
- Or open the "Actions" tab in the repo to view all workflow runs.

1. Fix Any Failing Checks

- If a workflow fails:Click the ❌ mark or open the "Actions" tabRead the logs to understand the failurePush changes to your branch to rerun the workflows
- If a workflow fails due to a one time issue, you can use Re-run all jobs button in the job page.

---

📁 Workflow Location

All workflows are stored in the repository under:

`.github/workflows/`

You do *not* need to edit these files unless you're maintaining the CI/CD pipeline.

By default `.github/workflows/cicd-pipeline.yml` should be present in order to use the default customer cicd pipeline templates.

s/cicd-pipeline.yml` should be present in order to use the default customer cicd pipeline templates.

This file points to the workflows under the repository: [https://github.com/inventanalytics/actions-workflow-templates](https://github.com/inventanalytics/actions-workflow-templates)

---

⚙️ Workflow Jobs Overview

The main workflow includes several reusable job definitions. Here’s what each one does:

tests / Build and Push Base Image

Builds and pushes the build image used for lint and unit tests.

tests / ci-pipeline

Runs the primary test suite.

Runs using the image created in `tests / Build and Push Base Image`

- Lint: Runs pylint and flake8
- Run Airflow Unit Tests: Run DAG unit tests
- Run Rocks Unit Tests: Run Rocks Extension unit tests
- Pokedex Metadata Check: Run pokedex metadata check
- Description: Deploys the built Airflow Docker image to the appropriate environment.Description: Deploys the built Airflow Docker image to the appropriate environment.

iate environment.Description: Deploys the built Airflow Docker image to the appropriate environment.

build-and-push-airflow-image

Build and Push Airflow Scheduler Image to Registry

deploy-airflow-image

Deploy kubernetes resources, including the airflow scheduler image created in `build-and-push-airflow-image`.

- Description: Deploys the built Airflow Docker image to the appropriate environment.
- Depends on: tests, build-and-push-airflow-image
- Triggered only on branches: main, dev, or any feature/* branch.
- Inputs: Uses the airflow_image_version output from the build-and-push-airflow-image job.

---

deploy_scripts

- Uses: .github/workflows/deploy-scripts.yml
- Description: Deploys auxiliary scripts and tools (e.g., DAGs, utilities).
- Depends on: tests
- Triggered only on branches: main, dev, or any feature/* branch.

### Jenkins → Github Actions Job Mapping

Audience: HR Department

Purpose: This guide explains how to submit an employee offboarding request using the Jira system to ensure timely and auditable removal of system access.

System: Jira Project: ADMIN Request Type: Offboarding Request

---

### ✅ When to Use This Guide

Use this process when:

- An employee is leaving the company (resignation, termination, contract end).
- A contractor or vendor no longer requires system access.

---

### ✏️ Step-by-Step Instructions

#### Step 1: Log in to Jira

- Go to your Jira workspace.
- Log in using your corporate credentials.

#### Step 2: Navigate to the ADMIN Project

- Click on Projects in the top navigation bar.
- Select ADMIN from the list.

#### Step 3: Start a New Offboarding Request

- Click the "Create" button (top navigation bar).
- In the Project dropdown, select ADMIN.
- In the Issue Type dropdown, select Offboarding Request.

#### Step 4: Fill Out the Offboarding Form

Complete the following fields:

metadata.title: How-To Guide: Submitting Offboarding Requests in Jira (Project: ADMIN)

content:
ect Offboarding Request.

#### Step 4: Fill Out the Offboarding Form

Complete the following fields:

| Field | Description | Required |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Employee Full Name | The name of the employee leaving | Yes |
| Department | The employee's department | Yes |
| Manager Name | Their direct manager | Optional |
| Termination Date | Final date of employment | Yes |
| Last Working Day | If different from termination date | Optional |
| Systems to Remove Access From | Select all applicable systems | Yes |
| Jira Username / Email | For accurate identity match | Yes |
| Notes / Exceptions | Special instructions (e.g., early laptop return) | Optional |
| Attach Exit Checklist | Upload if available | Optional |

#### Step 5: Submit the Request

- Click Create to submit the request.
- The IT team will be automatically notified.

---

### 🔄 What Happens Next?

metadata.title: How-To Guide: Submitting Offboarding Requests in Jira (Project: ADMIN)

content:
to submit the request.
- The IT team will be automatically notified.

---

### 🔄 What Happens Next?

- IT will review and revoke access within 24 hours.
- Status of the request can be monitored under the ADMIN project.
- Once completed, the ticket will be marked as Access Revoked and Closed.

---

### 📊 Compliance Note

Using Jira ensures:

- Traceability of all access removal actions
- Compliance with SOC 2 and ISO/IEC 27001
- A centralized audit trail for offboarding

---

### ❓ Need Help?

If you have questions or need access to Jira:

- Contact the IT team via Slack or at support@inventanalytics.com
- For urgent offboarding: call IT directly and follow up with a Jira request

---

Thank you for helping keep our systems secure and audit-ready!

metadata.title: How-To Guide: Submitting Offboarding Requests in Jira (Project: ADMIN)

1. 📩 Information Required Before Escalating Incident to Us

| Step | Checkpoint | Description |
| --- | --- | --- |
| G1 | Is the incident time clear? | Has the date and time of the issue been clearly provided? |
| G2 | Is the error message recorded? | Is there a screenshot, log snippet, or system error message available? |
| G3 | Have any troubleshooting steps been tried? | Have actions like refresh, retry, or alternative attempts been made? |
| G4 | Has there been any recent change? | Any recent deployment, configuration, or infrastructure change? |
| G5 | Which application and customer is affected? | What application is having the issue, and which customer(s) are impacted? |
| G6 | What asset or content is related? | Which DAG, job, report, or server is associated with the issue? |

1. 🟦 Airflow CheckList (DAG/Task Errors)

| A2 | Which task failed? | Task name and retry information |
| A3 | What exception is in the log? | Python error or connection issue? |
| A4 | Is there a queue/pool problem? | Is the task stuck behind other runs? |
| A5 | Is there a syntax error in the code? | Did the DAG break after the last deployment? |

| D2 | Cluster status | Was the cluster able to start? Not terminated? |
| D3 | Notebook exception | Is there a code exception or resource issue? |
| D4 | DBFS access | Is the mounted storage accessible? |
| D5 | Runtime changed? | Did the notebook switch to a different DBR version? |

# Installing Drata Agent App

1-) Login Drata :  [https://app.drata.com/](https://app.drata.com/)

2-) When you logged in you will see this screen below. Click on arrow on the Install Drata Agent tab.

-Click on the Download Drata Agent button.

-Find the option for the operating system of your pc then click on it for download.

-From now on the instructions will change for each operating system. Please scroll down and find the quides for your system.

## -Windows

ange for each operating system. Please scroll down and find the quides for your system.

## -Windows

1-) Find the downloaded app in the “Downloads” folder and double click on it for starting the installation. (If you can’t find it there you can check your browser’s download location).

-The app does not have a detailed installation wizard so don’t be confused if nothing show on screen.  A quick pop up for installation percentage could appear and close right away.

-When the installation done, navigate the app logo by clicking the arrow button at the bottom right corner on screen. You can click on it for opening the Drata Agent.

-Windows installation ends here. Please scroll down for registration part.

## -Linux

1-) Navigate the “Drata-Agent-linux.deb“ file for on your pc. It should be downloaded on your “Downloads” folder.

2-)Open a terminal and find and locate the terminal into the directory of the folder by using “cd“ command.

a terminal and find and locate the terminal into the directory of the folder by using “cd“ command.

3-) Use dpkg package manager for installing the app.

Installation script :

sudo dpkg -i Drata-Agent-linux-deb

-After the installation run the script below for allowing Drata Agent working continuously.

Script:

sudo sysctl -w kernel.apparmor_restrict_unprivileged_userns=0

4-) Navigate the app at the top right of the screen and double click for opening it.

-Linux installation ends here. Please scroll down for registration part.

## -Macbook

1-) Find the setup by checking your “Downloads“ folder or browser’s download pop-up.

2-) Double click on the setup app. On the opening screen below press and hold on the Drata Agent logo and carry it on the Applications folder.

3-) Find the app on the launchpad and double click for opening it.

-After opening it allow the permissions below.

pp on the launchpad and double click for opening it.

-After opening it allow the permissions below.

-Apple installation ends here. You can find the app at the top right corner. Please scroll down for registration part.

## Registering Drata Agent

1-) Open your Drara Agent and click on the” Go to My Drata” button. It redrects you to Drata website.

2-) Navigate the “Install Drata Agent“ section and click the arrow on it.

-Find the “Register Drata Agent” button and click on it. After clicking it a green line should appear at the bottom of the page.

-Go ahead and check you @invent.ai e-mail’s mailbox for registry e-mail from Drata. I should be similar like the image below.

-Click on the “Verify Drata Agent“ button. It should ask you for redirect you to Drata Agent app.

Note: Redirect button can be change for operating system or browser. Something similar like “Continue on (app name)“ , “Allow“ will work.

or operating system or browser. Something similar like “Continue on (app name)“ , “Allow“ will work.

-If everything goes right you will see this screen on your app. Then you can click okay and see the main screen.

##

## How to use Drata Agent

This is the main screen of Drata Agent App. It monitors your pc and checks the if the configurations completed or not.

You need to go check the incomplete tasks and complete them for compliance.

You can use help articles of Drata for completing your tasks.

# Installing Drata Agent App

1-) You can access the Drata application by clicking on the Drata icon on your Okta user dashboard.

[inventanalytics.okta.com](https://inventanalytics.okta.com)

2-) When you logged in you will see this screen below. Click on arrow on the Install Drata Agent tab.

-Click on the Download Drata Agent button.

-Find the option for the operating system of your pc then click on it for download.

-From now on the instructions will change for each operating system. Please scroll down and find the quides for your system.

tions will change for each operating system. Please scroll down and find the quides for your system.

## -Windows

1-) Find the downloaded app in the “Downloads” folder and double click on it for starting the installation. (If you can’t find it there you can check your browser’s download location).

-The app does not have a detailed installation wizard so don’t be confused if nothing show on screen. A quick pop up for installation percentage could appear and close right away.

-When the installation done, navigate the app logo by clicking the arrow button at the bottom right corner on screen. You can click on it for opening the Drata Agent.

-Windows installation ends here. Please scroll down for registration part.

## -Linux

1-) Navigate the “Drata-Agent-linux.deb“ file for on your pc. It should be downloaded on your “Downloads” folder.

2-)Open a terminal and find and locate the terminal into the directory of the folder by using “cd“ command.

a terminal and find and locate the terminal into the directory of the folder by using “cd“ command.

3-) Use dpkg package manager for installing the app.

Installation script :

sudo dpkg -i Drata-Agent-linux-deb

-After the installation run the script below for allowing Drata Agent working continuously.

Script:

sudo sysctl -w kernel.apparmor_restrict_unprivileged_userns=0

4-) Navigate the app at the top right of the screen and double click for opening it.

-Linux installation ends here. Please scroll down for registration part.

## -Macbook

1-) Find the setup by checking your “Downloads“ folder or browser’s download pop-up.

2-) Double click on the setup app. On the opening screen below press and hold on the Drata Agent logo and carry it on the Applications folder.

3-) Find the app on the launchpad and double click for opening it.

-After opening it allow the permissions below.

pp on the launchpad and double click for opening it.

-After opening it allow the permissions below.

-Apple installation ends here. You can find the app at the top right corner. Please scroll down for registration part.

## Registering Drata Agent

1-) Open your Drata Agent and click on the” Go to My Drata” button. It redirects you to Drata website.

2-) Navigate the “Install Drata Agent“ section and click the arrow on it.

-Find the “Register Drata Agent” button and click on it. After clicking it a green line should appear at the bottom of the page.

-Go ahead and check you @invent.ai e-mail’s mailbox for registry e-mail from Drata. I should be similar like the image below.

-Click on the “Verify Drata Agent“ button. It should ask you for redirect you to Drata Agent app.

Note: Redirect button can be change for operating system or browser. Something similar like “Continue on (app name)“ , “Allow“ will work.

or operating system or browser. Something similar like “Continue on (app name)“ , “Allow“ will work.

-If everything goes right you will see this screen on your app. Then you can click okay and see the main screen.

## How to use Drata Agent

This is the main screen of Drata Agent App. It monitors your pc and checks the if the configurations completed or not.

You need to go check the incomplete tasks and complete them for compliance.

You can use help articles of Drata for completing your tasks.

## Please contact for any questions or assistance:Alpha Teamslack: ask-alphateams: ask-alphae-mail: alpha-team@invent.ai

By following the steps below, you can easily complete the requirements on the Drata platform.

---

## 🔐 1. Log In

### 1.1. Log In to Your Okta Account

- Go to inventanalytics.okta.com and log in with your user credentials.

### 1.2. Open the Drata Application

- After logging in, click on the Drata icon in your Okta dashboard to access the Drata application.

---

## ✅ 2. Complete the Necessary Steps on Drata

### 2.1. Privacy Policy Agreement

- On the login screen, check the box for “I agree to Drata’s Privacy Notice.”
- Then click the "Continue" button to proceed.
- (You can review the details via the Privacy Notice link if you wish.)

---

## 📋 3. Three Steps to Complete

The "Enable MFA on Identity Provider" step will already be automatically marked as completed because Okta MFA is in use.

You are left with three steps to complete:

---

### ✅ 3.1. Review & Acknowledge Company Policies

It requires you to read and acknowledge the company policies.

Review & Acknowledge Company Policies

It requires you to read and acknowledge the company policies.

- You are required to read and acknowledge the company policies.
- Click on your name to view the policies and review each policy document.
- Then click the “Acknowledge Policy” button to confirm.
- Once confirmed, the step will be marked in green.

---

### 💻 3.2. Install the Drata Agent

You need to install the Drata Agent on your computer.

#### Why Is It Necessary?

- The Drata Agent automatically checks your computer’s security settings (disk encryption, screen lock, password policies, etc.).
- These checks ensure compliance with information security standards such as SOC 2 and ISO 27001.

#### How to Install?

- Follow the installation steps using the provided link.How to Install Drata Agent?
- Once the installation is complete, the step will be marked in green.

### 🎓 3.3. Complete Security Awareness Training

You need to complete the security awareness training.

# 🎓 3.3. Complete Security Awareness Training

You need to complete the security awareness training.

- By starting the training, you will gain knowledge about basic security concepts and practices.
- There may be test questions at the end of the training.
- Once you successfully complete the training, the step will be marked in green.

---

## 🎉 4. You're Done!

If you have completed all the steps, no further action is required.

If you encounter any issues or have any questions, you can reach us through the following communication channels:

- Slack: ask-alpha
- Teams: ask-alpha
- E-mail: alpha-team@invent.ai

content:
## Control Evidence – Object Storage Backup & Restore

### Control Objective

Ensure that object storage in Azure and AWS can be restored in case of accidental deletion, corruption, or modification.

---

## 1. Azure – Backup & Restore

Environment: Azure Storage Account – `inventbootsgrs`

Protection Configuration:

- Point-in-time restore for containers: Enabled – Maximum restore point: 2 days ago
- Soft delete for blobs: Enabled – Retention: 3 days
- Soft delete for containers: Enabled – Retention: 3 days
- Blob change feed tracking: Enabled

Restore Procedure (Soft Delete & Point-in-Time Restore):

1. Navigate to Azure Portal → Storage Account → inventbootsgrs.
2. Go to Data Protection to confirm settings.
3. Soft Delete Recovery:Go to Containers → select the container.Toggle Show Deleted Blobs.Select the deleted blob → click Restore.
4. Point-in-Time Restore:Go to Containers → click Restore.Choose a restore point up to 2 days ago.Confirm to revert container state.

Evidence:

click Restore.Choose a restore point up to 2 days ago.Confirm to revert container state.

Evidence:

- Azure Blob Restore Example 1
- Blob file recovery

---

## 2. AWS – Backup & Restore

Environment: AWS S3 Bucket – `invent-academy`

Protection Configuration:

- Bucket Versioning: Enabled
- MFA Delete: Disabled (not required for this control)

Restore Procedure (Version Recovery):

1. Navigate to AWS Console → S3 → Bucket → invent-academy.
2. Click Show versions in the Objects tab.
3. Locate the object with a Delete marker or an older version.
4. If deleted: Select the delete marker → click Delete (restores previous version).
5. If overwritten: Select the older version → Download and re-upload, or make it the current version.

⚠ Note: Once a specific version is permanently deleted, it cannot be recovered.

Evidence:

-
- S3 Bucket Restore Example 1
- S3 Bucket Restore Example 2 | ADMIN-8530
- S3 Bucket Restore Example 3 | ADMIN-8531

---

Example 1
- S3 Bucket Restore Example 2 | ADMIN-8530
- S3 Bucket Restore Example 3 | ADMIN-8531

---

## 3. Additional Protection – Delta Lake Table Versioning

Environment: All customer datasets in Delta Lake format

Protection Configuration:

- Table history retention: Minimum 1 week
- Allows point-in-time recovery of entire datasets (independent of storage layer)

Restore Procedure:

1. Open Delta Lake environment (Databricks or Spark SQL).
2. Run:DESCRIBE HISTORY <table_name>;
3. Identify version number/timestamp for restore point.
4. Run:SELECT * FROM <table_name> VERSION AS OF <version_number>;
5. Optionally overwrite table with restored version.

Evidence:

- https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ADMIN/pages/3633020935/Data+Recovery?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiOTk2MDliYzgyNGViNDg5Yzg2ZGExNTQ5YmYwYWM2ZjgiLCJwIjoiY29uZmx1ZW5jZS1jaGF0cy1pbnQifQ

atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiOTk2MDliYzgyNGViNDg5Yzg2ZGExNTQ5YmYwYWM2ZjgiLCJwIjoiY29uZmx1ZW5jZS1jaGF0cy1pbnQifQ

Our products use a Delta Lake architecture, which maintains a minimum of one week of table version history. This allows us to restore any dataset to its exact state at a chosen point in the last week, independent of the underlying storage.

In addition, we enable object/blob versioning at the storage account or bucket level. This means that even if a physical data file is changed or deleted, we can retrieve an earlier version from storage. Together, these provide two layers of recovery — one at the data lake table level, and one at the raw object storage level — which cover the intent of the backup and restore control.

Step-by-Step Request Submission

1. Access the SysAdmin Board in JIRAGo to the System Administration board in JIRA.Ensure you are logged in with your company email.
2. Create a New Permission Request TicketClick on Create Issue and select Permission Request work type.
3. SummaryAI API Key Permission Request for [Team/Project]
4. DescriptionPurpose: Explain why this key is required.Team / Project: Specify the team or project name.AI Provider: Choose between OpenAI or Google Gemini.Customer: Specify “Invent” for internal projects or the client name for external projects.Secret Manager / Key Vault: Select AWS, Azure, both, or leave blank if unsure.Authorized Members: List people who need access to this key.Models to Use: Specify which models (e.g., gpt-4.1-mini, gemini-1.5-flash).
5. Approver SelectionAs the task approver, you must select the manager associated with your team or department.
6. Post-Approval Communication & Key Generation

metadata.title: How to Submit an AI API Key Request

content:
the manager associated with your team or department.
6. Post-Approval Communication & Key Generation

- After the Approver Selection and first-level approval by your Team/Project Manager, the request is sent as a comment to the Sonic Team Admin (initiated by the Alpha team).
- The Sonic Team Admin will:Validate the request details.Confirm the correct placement of the API key within the dedicated project workspace (OpenAI or Google Gemini).Approve key creation only after ensuring all requirements and naming conventions are met.
- Once approved, the API key will be generated under the following conditions:The Alpha Team will:Stored in the correct Secret Manager (AWS or Azure) following the naming conventions.Tagged and labeled as specified (Project, Customer, AI Provider, Environment, ServerType).Restricted to the authorized members listed in the request.If the API key access will be made by a service account or a user, access should be granted according to the conditions listed here.

metadata.title: How to Submit an AI API Key Request

content:
de by a service account or a user, access should be granted according to the conditions listed here.

[https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1HNNre_-8vnQSLRApAeiDvKvXW7ig1xuMNuC9bx1rm0A/edit?gid=0#gid=0](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1HNNre_-8vnQSLRApAeiDvKvXW7ig1xuMNuC9bx1rm0A/edit?gid=0#gid=0)

1. Key Issuance Notification

- Once the key is generated, a notification is sent to the requestor via the JIRA comment thread.
- The notification includes:Confirmation that the API key is available.Secret Manager location (AWS or Azure).Authorized users and project/workspace details.

1. Key Usage & Compliance

- The API key must be referenced from the approved secret manager; direct usage in source code or config files is prohibited.
- Usage should follow the project guidelines, including token quotas and monitoring.
- Any suspected misuse must be reported immediately to the Alpha and Sonic teams.

1. Key Rotation & Expiry

metadata.title: How to Submit an AI API Key Request

content:
uspected misuse must be reported immediately to the Alpha and Sonic teams.

1. Key Rotation & Expiry

- API keys will have defined lifecycles and may require rotation based on project or security requirements.
- Expired or revoked keys must not be used; applications must fetch the updated key from the secret manager.

| US | No | No | No | Yes (prod-us-aks) |
| UAE | No | No | No | Yes (prod-uae-aks) |

Notes:

- Dev and Test clusters exist only in the EU region.
- Feature branches are deployed only to customertest-eu-aks.

EU region.
- Feature branches are deployed only to customertest-eu-aks.

### 🔹 1. Check your current version

```
aws --version

If your version is older than 2.11.0, you need to update.

```
msiexec.exe /i https://awscli.amazonaws.com/AWSCLIV2.msi /qn
```

> The /qn flag performs a silent installation.If you prefer a graphical installer, remove the /qn parameter.

### 🔹 3. Verify installation

```
aws --version
```

```
aws-cli/2.17.62 Python/3.11.9 Windows/10 exe/AMD64 prompt/off
```

## macOS

### 🔹 1. Check your current version

```
aws --version
```

If your version is older than 2.11.0, you need to update.

```
brew update && brew reinstall awscli
```

### 🔹 3. Manual installation (if Homebrew is not available)

metadata.title: AWS CLI v2 Installation and Upgrade Guide (Windows, macOS, Linux)

content:
rew update && brew reinstall awscli
```

### 🔹 3. Manual installation (if Homebrew is not available)

```
curl "https://awscli.amazonaws.com/AWSCLIV2.pkg" -o "AWSCLIV2.pkg"
sudo installer -pkg AWSCLIV2.pkg -target /
```

### 🔹 4. Verify installation

```
aws --version
```

---

## Linux

### 🔹 1. Check your current version

```
aws --version
```

If your version is older than 2.11.0, you need to update.

### 🔹 2. Download the latest release

```
curl "https://awscli.amazonaws.com/awscli-exe-linux-x86_64.zip" -o "awscliv2.zip"
```

### 🔹 3. Unzip and install (or update)

```
unzip awscliv2.zip
sudo ./aws/install --update
```

### 🔹 4. Verify installation

```
aws --version
```

(Ubuntu/Debian)

#### Prerequisites

Make sure you have curl, unzip, and sudo installed. You can install them with:

```
sudo apt update
sudo apt install curl unzip sudo -y
```

### 1- Install AWS CLI v2

1. Download the latest AWS CLI v2 installer:

```
curl "https://awscli.amazonaws.com/awscli-exe-linux-x86_64.zip" -o "awscliv2.zip"
```

1. Unzip and install (or update) AWS CLI:

```
unzip awscliv2.zip
sudo ./aws/install --update
```

1. Verify installation:

```
aws --version
```

Example output:

aws-cli/2.17.62 Python/3.11.9 Linux/5.15.0-70-generic exe/x86_64 prompt/off

### 2- Install Python 3

Most Linux distributions come with Python pre-installed. To install the latest version:

```
sudo apt install python3 python3-pip -y
```

Verify installation:

```
python3 --version
pip3 --version
```

### 3- Install Required Python Libraries

Install the necessary Python libraries for the project:

```
pip3 install boto3
```

### 4- Download Invent Python Scripts

5- Log in to AWS CLI Using the Script

Prod Account:

For the Prod account, navigate to the directory where you downloaded the file in Step 4 and run the following commands in the terminal.

```
python3 inventawsprod.py
```

When you run this script, you will be prompted to log in via Okta and then grant permission for the AWS CLI. Once completed, you should see the message:`All credentials written safely. The token is valid for 12 hours.` If you see this message, the process is complete.

You can verify that the process worked correctly by running the command:
aws s3 ls

Note: The command python inventawsprod.py generates a 12-hour AWS CLI token, which will expire after 12 hours. If you need to connect on a different day, you must run this command again to log in.

Before starting, we need to check if Homebrew, the package manager for macOS, is installed. You can verify this by running the command below.

```
brew --version
```

If you receive a “command not found” error, you can install Homebrew using the command below.

```
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"
```

Then, run the command below to add Homebrew’s installation directory to your terminal environment so that the brew command works in every session.

```
eval "$(/opt/homebrew/bin/brew shellenv)"
```

Next, use the brew update command to make sure Homebrew is up to date.

```
brew install awscli
```

After the installation is complete, verify the version:

```
aws --version
```

content:
### 1- Install AWS CLI v2

1. Download the AWS CLI v2 installer for Windows from the official link:

[https://awscli.amazonaws.com/AWSCLIV2.msi](https://awscli.amazonaws.com/AWSCLIV2.msi)

1. Install silently via Command Prompt (optional) or run the installer GUI:

```
msiexec.exe /i https://awscli.amazonaws.com/AWSCLIV2.msi /qn
```

- The /qn flag performs a silent installation.
- To use the GUI installer, simply run the .msi file without /qn.

1. Verify the installation:

```
aws --version
```

Example output:

aws-cli/2.17.62 Python/3.11.9 Windows/10 exe/AMD64 prompt/off

[https://www.python.org/downloads/windows/](https://www.python.org/downloads/windows/)

2. Verify installation:

```
python --version
pip --version
```

python inventawsprod.py

When you run this script, you will be prompted to log in via Okta and then grant permission for the AWS CLI. Once completed, you should see the message:`All credentials written safely. The token is valid for 12 hours.` If you see this message, the process is complete.

You can verify that the process worked correctly by running the command:
aws s3 ls

content:
Purpose of the AWS SSO Migration

At [invent.ai](http://invent.ai) , we are transitioning from traditional AWS IAM user-based access management to AWS IAM Identity Center (AWS SSO) in order to enhance security, scalability, and user experience across all AWS environments.

This migration aims to centralize and simplify how users access AWS resources while improving identity protection and compliance with security standards.

### Key Reasons for the Migration

🧩 Centralized Identity Management (Single Sign-On – SSO)

All users will now be able to access AWS through their Okta accounts with a single click.

This eliminates the need to manage separate AWS usernames and passwords for each user.

🔒 Enhanced Security

Permanent IAM user credentials (Access Key / Secret Key) will be replaced with temporary, limited-access credentials.

This significantly reduces the risk of credential exposure and improves auditability.

🧭 Simplified Role and Access Management

the risk of credential exposure and improves auditability.

🧭 Simplified Role and Access Management

Access will now be managed through team-based roles (e.g., *NebulaTeamRole, RocketTeamRole*).

This structure makes access management more secure and efficient — onboarding and offboarding processes become seamless.

New users will automatically inherit access permissions assigned to their teams.

Team permissions have been defined in collaboration with team leaders.

If additional permissions are needed, they will be adjusted on a team basis.

Managers should carefully review this when approving new access requests.

🧾 Improved Compliance and Visibility

Centralized authentication and access logging improve compliance with standards such as SOC 2 and ISO 27001.

User activities become more transparent and traceable.

### Outcomes of the Migration

Following this migration:

ies become more transparent and traceable.

### Outcomes of the Migration

Following this migration:

- AWS user management and access review processes will be simplified.
- Access request and approval flows will become more transparent.
- Access errors or permission mismatches will be minimized.
- Centralized logging will accelerate reporting during audits.

### Scope of the Migration

This migration applies only to individual user accounts.

Service accounts and customer AWS accounts are not affected and will continue to use the existing IAM user structure.

Similarly, CI/CD pipelines, automation accounts, and system-level accesses are also excluded from this migration.

### Required Documentation for Migration

- Accessing AWS Web Console via Okta
- AWS CLI Credentials Migration to AWS SSO

### Migration Plan

- Accessing AWS Web Console via Okta
- AWS CLI Credentials Migration to AWS SSO

### Migration Plan

- The migration process will begin with an official email announcement.
- 10 days after the announcement, all individual IAM user accounts will be disabled.
- 30 days after disablement, all IAM user accounts will be permanently deleted.

Note: If you have used your Access Key or Secret Key in any scripts, services, or configurations, please make sure to update them before your account is disabled.

### Support Process

During the migration, user access will be continuously monitored, and any issues will be resolved promptly by the support team.

If you experience any login or access issues, please open a ticket using the following template:

🔗 [AWS Access Issue Template (Web Login & CLI Login)]

### Summary

This migration is designed to improve both security and user experience for all [invent.ai](http://invent.ai) AWS users.

signed to improve both security and user experience for all [invent.ai](http://invent.ai) AWS users.

From now on, all AWS access will be managed entirely through Okta and AWS SSO, while legacy IAM user accounts will be gradually phased out.

The detailed migration timeline and required user actions will be shared in the upcoming official announcement email.

Hello,

If your Actions or Jenkins build raises errors like :

```
ERROR: (BadRequest) Too many Federated Identity Credentials have been assigned to the Managed Identity.
Code: BadRequest
Message: Too many Federated Identity Credentials have been assigned to the Managed Identity.
```

It is finally time for you to use Federated Credential Remover Pipeline

## What this pipeline does

The pipeline includes 2 separate workflows

The collective purpose of the two workflows is to allow an authorized user to cleanly and accurately remove obsolete Federated Identity Credentials (FICs) from a specific Azure User-Assigned Managed Identity, typically to clean up after deleted feature branches.

### Common Summary of the Two-Workflow Process

The entire process mimics a human-guided deletion wizard:

content:
on wizard:

1. Discovery (Workflow 1): The user triggers the first workflow (List Managed Identity Federated Credentials (Step 1)) by providing the target Customer Name and Resource Group. The workflow fetches a live list of all existing FICs on the target Managed Identity. It then presents this list as a clean, easy-to-read table in the GitHub Actions run summary, displaying the FIC Name (which is usually the branch name) and the Resource Group. This step ensures the user knows exactly what can be deleted.
2. Targeted Deletion (Workflow 2): After reviewing the list from Step 1, the user triggers the second workflow (Delete Managed Identity Federated Credential (Step 2)). This time, the user pastes the exact FIC Name they wish to delete into the input field, along with the Customer Name and Resource Group. The second workflow targeted Azure CLI command to destroy only the specified credential, thus completing the cleanup process without requiring high-level credentials to be exposed.

# Linux

---

Open a terminal and run the following command to download and install Tailscale from its public library:

a terminal and run the following command to download and install Tailscale from its public library:

```bash
sudo apt install curl
curl -fsSL https://tailscale.com/install.sh | sh
```

Tailscale runs as a service on linux machines, to enable it after installation you can run:

`sudo tailscale up`

Since you are running it for the first time it will ask for an authentication. Visit the page the command tells you to.

Proceed with “Sign in with Google” option.

Select Connect once you successfully login.

INV-NB-416 example, dependant on your computer name.

Your device is successfully registered to our network and you can start using the vpn from your cli.

You can confirm this via:

```bash
melih@ubumeli:~$ ip -4 a show tailscale0
5: tailscale0: <POINTOPOINT,MULTICAST,NOARP,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1280 qdisc fq_codel state UNKNOWN group default qlen 500
    inet 100.113.216.28/32 scope global tailscale0
melih@ubumeli:~$
```

KNOWN group default qlen 500
    inet 100.113.216.28/32 scope global tailscale0
melih@ubumeli:~$
```

If you managed to receive an ip address within the 100.0.0.0/32 block, congrats you are in the network.

To continue run the following command:

```bash
tailscale exit-node list

 IP                 HOSTNAME                        COUNTRY     CITY      STATUS
 100.72.55.37       eu-west.tailac106f.ts.net       -           -         -
 100.74.249.45      uae-north.tailac106f.ts.net     -           -         -
 100.114.108.46     us-east.tailac106f.ts.net       -           -         -

```

> Info: Exit Node: This is where your internet will be routed to the internet. If you select eu-west your internet will masked with our Ireland vpn server and vice versa. Same goes for the other options.eu-west > Connects to Irelandus-east > Connects to USA N. Virginiauae-north > Connects to United Arab Emirates

Connects to Irelandus-east > Connects to USA N. Virginiauae-north > Connects to United Arab Emirates

> Note: For best performance; We strongly recommend that you select the exit node, that is closest to your current location.

Assume the eu-west is the most feasible region for you to connect, run the following command to route your internet traffic to that VPN server:

```bash
sudo tailscale set --exit-node=100.72.55.37 # eu-west server ip address
```

or

```bash
sudo tailscale set --exit-node=eu-west.tailac106f.ts.net. # eu-west server hostname
```

This setting is persistent on your computer and the exit node selection will always remain when you restart your computer or the VPN service. (As long as you dont change it manually afterwards.)

You can stop the vpn service simply with: `sudo tailscale down`

Start it again with: `sudo tailscale up`
